{"uri": "2024-06-380346720", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "04:21:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T04:21:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T04:02:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/the-sun-rises-over-normandys-beaches-on-d-days-80th-anniversary/article_84e5340e-a8c7-5bfc-8c92-6b7135c25d77.html", "title": "The sun rises over Normandy's beaches on D-Day's 80th anniversary", "body": "The sun is rising again over Normandy beaches where soldiers fought and died exactly 80 years ago on D-Day\n\nUTAH BEACH, France (AP) -- As the sun sets on the D-Day generation, it's rising again over Normandy beaches where soldiers fought and died exactly 80 years ago, kicking off intense anniversary commemorations Thursday against the backdrop of renewed war in Europe, in Ukraine.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, make this anniversary particularly meaningful, mixing poignant remembrances for D-Day sacrifices with an Allied show of solidarity for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, among the guests.\n\nBut host France hasn't invited World War II ally Russia, citing its \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks.\"\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. The previous story is below.\n\nAs the sun sets on the D-Day generation, it will rise again Thursday over the Normandy beaches where the waves long ago washed away the blood and boot-steps of its soldiers, but where their exploits that helped end Adolf Hitler's tyranny are being remembered by the next generations, seeing war again in Europe, in Ukraine.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans who have pilgrimaged back to France, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine that has dashed hopes that lives and cities wouldn't again be laid to waste in Europe, are making the always poignant anniversaries of the June 6, 1944, Allied landings even more so 80 years on.\n\nAs now-centenarian veterans revisit old memories and fallen comrades buried in Normandy graves, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's presence at D-Day commemorations with world leaders -- including U.S. President Joe Biden -- who are supporting his country's fight against Russia's invasion will inevitably fuse together World War II's awful past with the fraught present on Thursday.\n\nThe break of dawn almost eight decades exactly after Allied troops waded ashore under hails of gunfire on five code-named beaches -- Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword -- will kick off a day of remembrance by Allied nations now standing together again behind Ukraine -- and with World War II ally Russia not invited by host France. It cited Russia's \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks\" for the snub.\n\nWith the dead and wounded on both sides in Ukraine estimated in the hundreds of thousands, commemorations for the more than 4,400 Allied dead on D-Day and many tens of thousands more, including French civilians, killed in the ensuing Battle of Normandy are tinged with concerns that World War II lessons are being lost.\n\n\"There are things worth fighting for,\" said World War II veteran Walter Stitt, who fought in tanks and turns 100 in July, as he visited Omaha Beach this week. \"Although I wish there was another way to do it than to try to kill each other.\"\n\n\"We'll learn one of these days, but I won't be around for that,\" he said.\n\nConscious of the inevitability that major D-Day anniversaries will soon take place without World War II veterans, huge throngs of aficionados in uniforms and riding vehicles of the time, and tourists soaking up the spectacle, have flooded Normandy for the 80th anniversary.\n\nThe fair-like atmosphere fueled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell, leave open the question of what meaning anniversaries will have once the veterans are gone.\n\nBut at the 80th, they're the VIPs of commemorations across the Normandy coast where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler's defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\n\nThose who traveled to Normandy include women who were among the millions who built bombers, tanks and other weaponry and played other vital World War II roles that were long overshadowed by the combat exploits of men.\n\n\"We weren't doing it for honors and awards. We were doing it to save our country. And we ended up helping save the world,\" said 98-year-old Anna Mae Krier, who worked as a riveter building B-17 and B-29 bombers.\n\nFeted where ever they go in wheelchairs and walking with canes, veterans are using their voices to repeat their message they hope will live eternal: Never forget.\n\n\"To know the amount of people who were killed here, just amazing,\" 98-year-old Allan Chatwin, who served with the U.S. Navy in the Pacific, said as he visited Omaha, the deadliest of the Allied beaches on D-Day.\n\nHe quickly added: \"I don't know that amazing is the word.\"\n\nMore from this {"uri": "8164407268", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "09:53:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T09:53:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T09:52:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.mercurynews.com/2024/06/05/the-sun-rises-over-normandys-beaches-on-d-days-80th-anniversary/", "title": "The sun rises over Normandy's beaches on D-Day's 80th anniversary", "body": "UTAH BEACH, France (AP) -- As the sun sets on the D-Day generation, it rose again over Normandy beaches where soldiers fought and died exactly 80 years ago Thursday, kicking off intense anniversary commemorations against the backdrop of renewed war in Europe, in Ukraine.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans who have pilgrimaged back to France, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine that has dashed hopes that lives and cities wouldn't again be laid to waste in Europe, are making the poignant anniversary of the June 6, 1944, Allied landings even more so 80 years on.\n\nAs now-centenarian veterans revisit old memories and fallen comrades buried in Normandy graves, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's presence at D-Day commemorations with world leaders who are supporting Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion -- including United States President Joe Biden -- will inevitably fuse together World War II's awful past with the fraught present on Thursday.\n\nThe break of dawn almost eight decades exactly after Allied troops waded ashore under hails of gunfire on five code-named beaches -- Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword -- kicked off a day of remembrance by Allied nations now standing together again behind Ukraine -- and with World War II ally Russia not invited by host France. It cited Russia's \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks\" for the snub.\n\nWith the dead and wounded on both sides in Ukraine estimated in the hundreds of thousands, commemorations for the more than 4,400 Allied dead on D-Day and many tens of thousands more, including French civilians, killed in the ensuing Battle of Normandy are tinged with concerns that World War II lessons are being lost.\n\n\"There are things worth fighting for,\" said World War II veteran Walter Stitt, who fought in tanks and turns 100 in July, as he visited Omaha Beach this week. \"Although I wish there was another way to do it than to try to kill each other.\"\n\n\"We'll learn one of these days, but I won't be around for that,\" he said.\n\nConscious of the inevitability that major D-Day anniversaries will soon take place without World War II veterans, huge throngs of aficionados in uniforms and riding vehicles of the time, and tourists soaking up the spectacle, have flooded Normandy for the 80th anniversary.\n\n\"It's so historic and we just have to remember the sacrifices of everybody who gave us our freedom,\" said Becky Kraubetz, a Briton now living in Florida whose grandfather served with the British Army during World War II and was captured in Malta.\n\n\"It gives you goosebumps, everything that happened here. Imagine just jumping into the water, freezing cold,\" the 54-year-old said as she gazed across the English Channel, tears in her eyes. \"The bravery, the courage, for people to face that is just unbelievable -- very, very humbled to be here.\"\n\nShe was among a crowd of thousands of people that stretched for several kilometers (miles) along Utah Beach, the westernmost of the D-Day beaches.\n\nIn a quiet spot away from the official ceremonies, France's Christophe Receveur performed his own tribute, unfurling an American flag he had bought on a trip to Pennsylvania to honor those who died on D-Day.\n\n\"To forget them is to let them die all over again,\" the 57-year-old said as he and his daughter, Julie, then carefully refolded the flag into a tight triangle, adding that those now dying in Ukraine fighting the invading Russian army were also on his mind.\n\n\"All these troops came to liberate a country that they didn't know for an ideology -- democracy, freedom -- that is under severe strain now,\" he said.\n\nThe fair-like atmosphere fueled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell, leave open the question of what meaning anniversaries will have once the veterans are gone.\n\nBut at the 80th, they're the VIPs of commemorations across the Normandy coast where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler's defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\n\n\"They really were the golden generation, those 17-, 18-year-old guys doing something so brave,\" said James Baker, a 56-year-old from the Netherlands, reflecting as dawn broke on Utah Beach.\n\nFarther up the coast on Gold Beach, a military bagpiper played at precisely the time that British troops landed there 80 years ago.\n\nThe United Kingdom's King Charles III and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak were among those at a ceremony later in the day to honor the troops who landed there and on Sword Beach, while Prince William and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau joined others at ceremony for the Canadian troops who landed on Juno Beach.\n\nIn his address, the king told the crowd that the world was fortunate that a generation \"did not flinch\" when they were called upon.\n\n\"Our obligation to remember what they stood for and what they achieved for us all can never diminish,\" he said.\n\nSpeaking in French, Charles also paid tribute to the \"unimaginable number\" of French civilians killed in the battle for Normandy, and the bravery and sacrifice of the French Resistance.\n\nBiden was to take part in a ceremony later at the American cemetery overlooking Omaha Beach.\n\nThose who traveled to Normandy include women who were among the millions who built bombers, tanks and other weaponry and played other vital World War II roles that were long overshadowed by the combat exploits of men.\n\n\"We weren't doing it for honors and awards. We were doing it to save our country. And we ended up helping save the world,\" said 98-year-old Anna Mae Krier, who worked as a riveter building B-17 and B-29 bombers.\n\nFeted where ever they go in wheelchairs and walking with canes, veterans are using their voices to repeat their message they hope will live eternal: Never forget.\n\n\"To know the amount of people who were killed here, just amazing,\" 98-year-old Allan Chatwin, who served with the U.S. Navy in the Pacific, said as he visited Omaha, the deadliest of the Allied beaches on D-Day.\n\nHe quickly added: \"I don't know that amazing is the word.\"", "source": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "wgt": 17}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/History", "label": "dmoz/Society/History", "wgt": 23}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Military", "label": "dmoz/Society/Military", "wgt": 21}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Military/Veterans", "label": "dmoz/Society/Military/Veterans", "wgt": 19}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Strength_Sports/Tug-of-War", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Strength Sports/Tug-of-War", "wgt": 16}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 79}], "image": "https://www.mercurynews.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/APTOPIX_D-Day_80th_Anniversary_US_Veterans_19100.jpg?w=640", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9628959", "eventUri": "eng-9628959", "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "France"}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.7254901960784313, "wgt": 212, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-380843274", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:19:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:19:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:01:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/as-the-world-marks-80th-anniversary-of-d-day-landings-renewed-war-in-europe-is/article_84e5340e-a8c7-5bfc-8c92-6b7135c25d77.html", "title": "As the world marks 80th anniversary of D-Day landings, renewed war in Europe is on minds of many", "body": "Twelve U.S. and British World War II veterans have been given Legion of Honor awards by French President Emmanuel Macron on the 80th anniversary of D-Day\n\nUTAH BEACH, France (AP) -- Twelve U.S. and British World War II veterans were given Legion of Honor awards by French President Emmanuel Macron on Thursday, the 80th anniversary of D-Day.\n\nMacron pinned medals on the 11 Americans and one Briton at a ceremony at the American Cemetery overlooking Omaha Beach, attended by U.S. President Joe Biden.\n\n\"You came here because the free world needed each and every one of you, and you answered the call,'' Macron said. ''You came here to make France a free nation. You're back here today at home, if I may say.\"\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nUTAH BEACH, France (AP) -- Leaders, veterans and visitors from around the world paid tribute Thursday to the D-Day generation in moving ceremonies on and around the Normandy beaches where the Allies landed exactly 80 years ago, with the war in Ukraine on the minds of many and a common message that tyranny cannot be permitted to prevail.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans who have pilgrimaged back to France, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine that has dashed hopes that lives and cities wouldn't again be laid to waste in Europe, are making the poignant anniversary of the June 6, 1944, Allied landings even more so.\n\nThe break of dawn eight decades after Allied troops waded ashore under hails of gunfire on five code-named beaches -- Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword -- kicked off a day of remembrance by Allied nations now standing together again behind Ukraine -- and with World War II ally Russia not invited by host France. It cited Russia's \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks\" for the snub.\n\nWith the dead and wounded on both sides in Ukraine estimated in the hundreds of thousands, commemorations for the more than 4,400 Allied dead on D-Day and many tens of thousands more, including French civilians, killed in the ensuing Battle of Normandy are tinged with concerns that World War II lessons are being lost.\n\n\"There are things worth fighting for,\" said World War II veteran Walter Stitt, who fought in tanks and turns 100 in July, as he visited Omaha Beach this week. \"Although I wish there was another way to do it than to try to kill each other.\"\n\n\"We'll learn one of these days, but I won't be around for that,\" he said.\n\nAs now-centenarian veterans revisit old memories and fallen comrades buried in Normandy graves, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's presence at the D-Day commemorations with world leaders who are supporting Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion -- including U.S. President Joe Biden -- will inevitably fuse together World War II's awful past with the fraught present.\n\nConscious of the inevitability that major D-Day anniversaries will soon take place without World War II veterans, huge throngs of aficionados in uniforms and riding vehicles of the time, and tourists soaking up the spectacle, flooded Normandy for the 80th anniversary.\n\n\"It's so historic and we just have to remember the sacrifices of everybody who gave us our freedom,\" said Becky Kraubetz, a Briton now living in Florida whose grandfather served with the British Army during World War II and was captured in Malta.\n\n\"It gives you goosebumps, everything that happened here. Imagine just jumping into the water, freezing cold,\" the 54-year-old said as she gazed across the English Channel, tears in her eyes. \"The bravery, the courage, for people to face that is just unbelievable -- very, very humbled to be here.\"\n\nShe was among a crowd of thousands of people that stretched for several kilometers (miles) along Utah Beach, the westernmost of the D-Day beaches.\n\nIn a quiet spot away from the official ceremonies, France's Christophe Receveur performed his own tribute, unfurling an American flag he had bought on a trip to Pennsylvania to honor those who died on D-Day.\n\n\"To forget them is to let them die all over again,\" the 57-year-old said as he and his daughter, Julie, then carefully refolded the flag into a tight triangle, adding that those now dying in Ukraine fighting the invading Russian army were also on his mind.\n\n\"All these troops came to liberate a country that they didn't know for an ideology -- democracy, freedom -- that is under severe strain now,\" he said.\n\nThe fair-like atmosphere fueled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell, leave open the question of what meaning anniversaries will have once the veterans are gone.\n\nBut at the 80th, they're the VIPs of commemorations across the Normandy coast where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler's defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\n\n\"They really were the golden generation, those 17-, 18-year-old guys doing something so brave,\" said James Baker, a 56-year-old from the Netherlands, reflecting as dawn broke on Utah Beach.\n\nFarther up the coast on Gold Beach, a military bagpiper played at precisely the time that British troops landed there 80 years ago.\n\nThe United Kingdom's King Charles III and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak were among those at a ceremony later in the day to honor the troops who landed there and on Sword Beach, while Prince William and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau joined others at ceremony for the Canadian troops who landed on Juno Beach.\n\nIn his address, the king told the crowd that the world was fortunate that a generation \"did not flinch\" when they were called upon.\n\n\"Our obligation to remember what they stood for and what they achieved for us all can never diminish,\" he said.\n\nSpeaking in French, Charles also paid tribute to the \"unimaginable number\" of French civilians killed in the battle for Normandy, and the bravery and sacrifice of the French Resistance.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron pledged that ''France will never forget'' those who fought to liberate his country.\n\nBiden was to take part in a ceremony later at the American cemetery overlooking Omaha Beach.\n\nThose who traveled to Normandy include women who were among the millions who built bombers, tanks and other weaponry and played other vital World War II roles that were long overshadowed by the combat exploits of men.\n\n\"We weren't doing it for honors and awards. We were doing it to save our country. And we ended up helping save the world,\" said 98-year-old Anna Mae Krier, who worked as a riveter building B-17 and B-29 bombers.\n\nFeted where ever they go in wheelchairs and walking with canes, veterans are using their voices to repeat their message they hope will live eternal: Never forget.\n\n\"To know the amount of people who were killed here, just amazing,\" 98-year-old Allan Chatwin, who served with the U.S. Navy in the Pacific, said as he visited Omaha, the deadliest of the Allied beaches on D-Day.\n\nHe quickly added: \"I don't know that amazing is the word.\"\n\nMore from this section\n\nAmerican Pacific Mortgage Picks Fee Chaser by LenderLogix to Collect Upfront Borrower Fees\n\nClick n' Close to Receive Top Lender Award at USDA's Single Family Housing Guaranteed Loan Program Ceremony\n\nMontana US Sen. "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "wgt": 18}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/History", "label": "dmoz/Society/History", "wgt": 23}, {"uri": "https://mynorthwest.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/MYNW_Facebookj.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9628959", "eventUri": "eng-9628959", "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "France"}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.7411764705882353, "wgt": 212, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8164299870", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "08:48:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T08:48:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T08:47:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://whdh.com/news/the-sun-rises-over-normandys-beaches-on-d-days-80th-anniversary/", "title": "The sun rises over Normandy's beaches on D-Day's 80th anniversary - Boston News, Weather, Sports | WHDH 7News", "body": "UTAH BEACH, France (AP) -- As the sun sets on the D-Day generation, it rose again over Normandy beaches where soldiers fought and died exactly 80 years ago Thursday, kicking off intense anniversary commemorations against the backdrop of renewed war in Europe, in Ukraine.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans who have pilgrimaged back to France, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine that has dashed hopes that lives and cities wouldn't again be laid to waste in Europe, are making the poignant anniversary of the June 6, 1944, Allied landings even more so 80 years on.\n\nAs now-centenarian veterans revisit old memories and fallen comrades buried in Normandy graves, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's presence at D-Day commemorations with world leaders who are supporting Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion -- including United States President Joe Biden -- will inevitably fuse together World War II's awful past with the fraught present on Thursday.\n\nThe break of dawn almost eight decades exactly after Allied troops waded ashore under hails of gunfire on five code-named beaches -- Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword -- kicked off a day of remembrance by Allied nations now standing together again behind Ukraine -- and with World War II ally Russia not invited by host France. It cited Russia's \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks\" for the snub.\n\nWith the dead and wounded on both sides in Ukraine estimated in the hundreds of thousands, commemorations for the more than 4,400 Allied dead on D-Day and many tens of thousands more, including French civilians, killed in the ensuing Battle of Normandy are tinged with concerns that World War II lessons are being lost.\n\n\"There are things worth fighting for,\" said World War II veteran Walter Stitt, who fought in tanks and turns 100 in July, as he visited Omaha Beach this week. \"Although I wish there was another way to do it than to try to kill each other.\"\n\n\"We'll learn one of these days, but I won't be around for that,\" he said.\n\nConscious of the inevitability that major D-Day anniversaries will soon take place without World War II veterans, huge throngs of aficionados in uniforms and riding vehicles of the time, and tourists soaking up the spectacle, have flooded Normandy for the 80th anniversary.\n\n\"It's so historic and we just have to remember the sacrifices of everybody who gave us our freedom,\" said Becky Kraubetz, a Briton now living in Florida whose grandfather served with the British Army during World War II and was captured in Malta.\n\n\"It gives you goosebumps, everything that happened here. Imagine just jumping into the water, freezing cold,\" the 54-year-old said as she gazed across the English Channel, tears in her eyes. \"The bravery, the courage, for people to face that is just unbelievable -- very, very humbled to be here.\"\n\nShe was among a crowd of thousands of people that stretched for several kilometers (miles) along Utah beach, the westernmost of the D-Day beaches.\n\nIn a quiet spot away from the official ceremonies, France's Christophe Receveur performed his own tribute, unfurling an American flag he had bought on a trip to Pennsylvania to honor those who died on D-Day.\n\n\"To forget them is to let them die all over again,\" the 57-year-old said as he and his daughter, Julie, then carefully refolded the flag into a tight triangle, adding that those now dying in Ukraine fighting the invading Russian army were also on his mind.\n\n\"All these troops came to liberate a country that they didn't know for an ideology -- democracy, freedom -- that is under severe strain now,\" he said.\n\nThe fair-like atmosphere fueled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell, leave open the question of what meaning anniversaries will have once the veterans are gone.\n\nBut at the 80th, they're the VIPs of commemorations across the Normandy coast where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler's defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\n\n\"They really were the golden generation, those 17-, 18-year-old guys doing something so brave,\" said James Baker, a 56-year-old from the Netherlands, reflecting as dawn broke on Utah Beach.\n\nFarther up the coast on Gold beach, a military bagpiper played at precisely the time that British troops landed there 80 years ago.\n\nU.K. King Charles III and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak were to take part in a ceremony later in the day to honor them and the British troops who also landed on Sword beach, while Prince William was set to participate in a ceremony for the Canadian troops who landed on Juno beach that will also include Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.\n\nBiden was to take part in a ceremony at the American cemetery overlooking Omaha beach.\n\nThose who traveled to Normandy include women who were among the millions who built bombers, tanks and other weaponry and played other vital World War II roles that were long overshadowed by the combat exploits of men.\n\n\"We weren't doing it for honors and awards. We were doing it to save our country. And we ended up helping save the world,\" said 98-year-old Anna Mae Krier, who worked as a riveter building B-17 and B-29 bombers.\n\nFeted where ever they go in wheelchairs and walking with canes, veterans are using their voices to repeat their message they hope will live eternal: Never forget.\n\n\"To know the amount of people who were killed here, just amazing,\" 98-year-old Allan Chatwin, who served with the U.S. Navy in the Pacific, said as he visited Omaha, the deadliest of the Allied beaches on D-Day.\n\nHe quickly added: \"I don't know that amazing is the word.\"\n\n(Copyright (c) 2024 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truck", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Truck"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9628959", "eventUri": "eng-9628959", "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "France"}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.7411764705882353, {"uri": "2024-06-380677329", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "10:02:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T10:02:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T10:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.kcra.com/article/d-days-80th-anniversary/61013290", "title": "The sun rises over Normandy's beaches on D-Day's 80th anniversary", "body": "As the sun sets on the D-Day generation, it rose again over Normandy beaches where soldiers fought and died exactly 80 years ago Thursday, kicking off intense anniversary commemorations against the backdrop of renewed war in Europe, in Ukraine.Ever-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans who have pilgrimaged back to France, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine that has dashed hopes that lives and cities wouldn't again be laid to waste in Europe, are making the poignant anniversary of the June 6, 1944, Allied landings even more so 80 years on.As now-centenarian veterans revisit old memories and fallen comrades buried in Normandy graves, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's presence at D-Day commemorations with world leaders who are supporting Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion -- including President Joe Biden -- will inevitably fuse together World War II's awful past with the fraught present on Thursday.The break of dawn almost eight decades exactly after Allied troops waded ashore under hails of gunfire on five code-named beaches -- Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword -- kicked off a day of remembrance by Allied nations now standing together again behind Ukraine -- and with World War II ally Russia not invited by host France. It cited Russia's \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks\" for the snub.With the dead and wounded on both sides in Ukraine estimated in the hundreds of thousands, commemorations for the more than 4,400 Allied dead on D-Day and many tens of thousands more, including French civilians, killed in the ensuing Battle of Normandy are tinged with concerns that World War II lessons are being lost.\"There are things worth fighting for,\" said World War II veteran Walter Stitt, who fought in tanks and turns 100 in July, as he visited Omaha Beach this week. \"Although I wish there was another way to do it than to try to kill each other.\"\"We'll learn one of these days, but I won't be around for that,\" he said.Conscious of the inevitability that major D-Day anniversaries will soon take place without World War II veterans, huge throngs of aficionados in uniforms and riding vehicles of the time, and tourists soaking up the spectacle, have flooded Normandy for the 80th anniversary.\"It's so historic and we just have to remember the sacrifices of everybody who gave us our freedom,\" said Becky Kraubetz, a Briton now living in Florida whose grandfather served with the British Army during World War II and was captured in Malta.\"It gives you goosebumps, everything that happened here. Imagine just jumping into the water, freezing cold,\" the 54-year-old said as she gazed across the English Channel, tears in her eyes. \"The bravery, the courage, for people to face that is just unbelievable -- very, very humbled to be here.\"She was among a crowd of thousands of people that stretched for several miles along Utah Beach, the westernmost of the D-Day beaches.In a quiet spot away from the official ceremonies, France's Christophe Receveur performed his own tribute, unfurling an American flag he had bought on a trip to Pennsylvania to honor those who died on D-Day.\"To forget them is to let them die all over again,\" the 57-year-old said as he and his daughter, Julie, then carefully refolded the flag into a tight triangle, adding that those now dying in Ukraine fighting the invading Russian army were also on his mind.\"All these troops came to liberate a country that they didn't know for an ideology -- democracy, freedom -- that is under severe strain now,\" he said.The fair-like atmosphere fueled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell, leave open the question of what meaning anniversaries will have once the veterans are gone.But at the 80th, they're the VIPs of commemorations across the Normandy coast where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler's defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\"They really were the golden generation, those 17-, 18-year-old guys doing something so brave,\" said James Baker, a 56-year-old from the Netherlands, reflecting as dawn broke on Utah Beach.Farther up the coast on Gold Beach, a military bagpiper played at precisely the time that British troops landed there 80 years ago.The United Kingdom's King Charles III and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak were among those at a ceremony later in the day to honor the troops who landed there and on Sword Beach, while Prince William and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau joined others at ceremony for the Canadian troops who landed on Juno Beach.In his address, the king told the crowd that the world was fortunate that a generation \"did not flinch\" when they were called upon.\"Our obligation to remember what they stood for and what they achieved for us all can never diminish,\" he said.Speaking in French, Charles also paid tribute to the \"unimaginable number\" of French civilians killed in the battle for Normandy, and the bravery and sacrifice of the French Resistance.Biden was to take part in a ceremony later at the American cemetery overlooking Omaha Beach.Those who traveled to Normandy include women who were among the millions who built bombers, tanks and other weaponry and played other vital World War II roles that were long overshadowed by the combat exploits of men.\"We weren't doing it for honors and awards. We were doing it to save our country. And we ended up helping save the world,\" said 98-year-old Anna Mae Krier, who worked as a riveter building B-17 and B-29 bombers.Feted where ever they go in wheelchairs and walking with canes, veterans are using their voices to repeat their message they hope will live eternal: Never forget.\"To know the amount of people who were killed here, just amazing,\" 98-year-old Allan Chatwin, who served with the U.S. Navy in the Pacific, said as he visited Omaha, the deadliest of the Allied beaches on D-Day.He quickly added: \"I don't know that amazing is the word.\"\n\nAs the sun sets on the D-Day generation, it rose again over Normandy beaches where soldiers fought and died exactly 80 years ago Thursday, kicking off intense anniversary commemorations against the backdrop of renewed war in Europe, in Ukraine.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans who have pilgrimaged back to France, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine that has dashed hopes that lives and cities wouldn't again be laid to waste in Europe, are making the poignant anniversary of the June 6, 1944, Allied landings even more so 80 years on.\n\nAs now-centenarian veterans revisit old memories and fallen comrades buried in Normandy graves, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's presence at D-Day commemorations with world leaders who are supporting Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion -- including President Joe Biden -- will inevitably fuse together World War II's awful past with the fraught present on Thursday.\n\nThe break of dawn almost eight decades exactly after Allied troops waded ashore under hails of gunfire on five code-named beaches -- Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword -- kicked off a day of remembrance by Allied nations now standing together again behind Ukraine -- and with World War II ally Russia not invited by host France. It cited Russia's \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks\" for the snub.\n\nWith the dead and wounded on both sides in Ukraine estimated in the hundreds of thousands, commemorations for the more than 4,400 Allied dead on D-Day and many tens of thousands more, including French civilians, killed in the ensuing Battle of Normandy are tinged with concerns that World War II lessons are being lost.\n\n\"There are things worth fighting for,\" said World War II veteran Walter Stitt, who fought in tanks and turns 100 in July, as he visited Omaha Beach this week. \"Although I wish there was another way to do it than to try to kill each other.\"\n\n\"We'll learn one of these days, but I won't be around for that,\" he said.\n\nConscious of the inevitability that major D-Day anniversaries will soon take place without World War II veterans, huge throngs of aficionados in uniforms and riding vehicles of the time, and tourists soaking up the spectacle, have flooded Normandy for the 80th anniversary.\n\n\"It's so historic and we just have to remember the sacrifices of everybody who gave us our freedom,\" said Becky Kraubetz, a Briton now living in Florida whose grandfather served with the British Army during World War II and was captured in Malta.\n\n\"It gives you goosebumps, everything that happened here. Imagine just jumping into the water, freezing cold,\" the 54-year-old said as she gazed across the English Channel, tears in her eyes. \"The bravery, the courage, for people to face that is just unbelievable -- very, very humbled to be here.\"\n\nShe was among a crowd of thousands of people that stretched for several miles along Utah Beach, the westernmost of the D-Day beaches.\n\nIn a quiet spot away from the official ceremonies, France's Christophe Receveur performed his own tribute, unfurling an American flag he had bought on a trip to Pennsylvania to honor those who died on D-Day.\n\n\"To forget them is to let them die all over again,\" the 57-year-old said as he and his daughter, Julie, then carefully refolded the flag into a tight triangle, adding that those now dying in Ukraine fighting the invading Russian army were also on his mind.\n\n\"All these troops came to liberate a country that they didn't know for an ideology -- democracy, freedom -- that is under severe strain now,\" he said.\n\nThe fair-like atmosphere fueled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell, leave open the question of what meaning anniversaries will have once the veterans are gone.\n\nBut at the 80th, they're the VIPs of commemorations across the Normandy coast where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler's defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\n\n\"They really were the golden generation, those 17-, 18-year-old guys doing something so brave,\" said James Baker, a 56-year-old from the Netherlands, reflecting as dawn broke on Utah Beach.\n\nFarther up the coast on Gold Beach, a military bagpiper played at precisely the time that British troops landed there 80 years ago.\n\nThe United Kingdom's King Charles III and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak were among those at a ceremony later in the day to honor the troops who landed there and on Sword Beach, while Prince William and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau joined others at ceremony for the Canadian troops who landed on Juno Beach.\n\nIn his address, the king told the crowd that the world was fortunate that a generation \"did not flinch\" when they were called upon.\n\n\"Our obligation to remember what they stood for and what they achieved for us all can never diminish,\" he said.\n\nSpeaking in French, Charles also paid tribute to the \"unimaginable number\" of French civilians killed in the battle for Normandy, and the bravery and sacrifice of the French Resistance.\n\nBiden was to take part in a ceremony later at the American cemetery overlooking Omaha Beach.\n\nThose who traveled to Normandy include women who were among the millions who built bombers, tanks and other weaponry and played other vital World War II roles that were long overshadowed by the combat exploits of men.\n\n\"We weren't doing it for honors and awards. We were doing it to save our country. And we ended up helping save the world,\" said 98-year-old Anna Mae Krier, who worked as a riveter building B-17 and B-29 bombers.\n\nFeted where ever they go in wheelchairs and walking with canes, veterans are using their voices to repeat their message they hope will live eternal: Never forget.\n\n\"To know the amount of people who were killed here, just amazing,\" 98-year-old Allan Chatwin, who served with the U.S. Navy in the Pacific, said as he visited Omaha, the deadliest of the Allied beaches on D-Day.\n\nHe quickly added: \"I don't know that amazing is the word.\"", "source": {"uri": "8164665734", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:26:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:26:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:25:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/world/2024/06/501_376129.html", "title": "As world marks 80th anniversary of D-Day landings, renewed war in Europe is on minds of many", "body": "France's President Emmanuel Macron, second from left, his wife Brigitte, left, U.S. President Joe Biden, second from right, and his wife Dr. Jill Biden attend a commemorative ceremony for the 80th anniversary of D-Day landings in Normandy at American War Cemetery in Colleville-sur-Mer, France, Thursday. EPA-Yonhap\n\nLeaders, veterans and visitors from around the world paid tribute Thursday to the D-Day generation in moving ceremonies on and around the Normandy beaches where the Allies landed exactly 80 years ago, with the war in Ukraine on the minds of many and a common message that tyranny cannot be permitted to prevail.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans who have pilgrimaged back to France, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine that has dashed hopes that lives and cities wouldn't again be laid to waste in Europe, are making the poignant anniversary of the June 6, 1944, Allied landings even more so.\n\nThe break of dawn eight decades after Allied troops waded ashore under hails of gunfire on five code-named beaches -- Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword -- kicked off a day of remembrance by Allied nations now standing together again behind Ukraine -- and with World War II ally Russia not invited by host France. It cited Russia's \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks\" for the snub.\n\nWith the dead and wounded on both sides in Ukraine estimated in the hundreds of thousands, commemorations for the more than 4,400 Allied dead on D-Day and many tens of thousands more, including French civilians , killed in the ensuing Battle of Normandy are tinged with concerns that World War II lessons are being lost .\n\n\"There are things worth fighting for,\" said World War II veteran Walter Stitt, who fought in tanks and turns 100 in July, as he visited Omaha Beach this week. \"Although I wish there was another way to do it than to try to kill each other.\"\n\n\"We'll learn one of these days, but I won't be around for that,\" he said.\n\nAs now-centenarian veterans revisit old memories and fallen comrades buried in Normandy graves , Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's presence at the D-Day commemorations with world leaders who are supporting Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion -- including U.S. President Joe Biden -- will inevitably fuse together World War II's awful past with the fraught present.\n\nConscious of the inevitability that major D-Day anniversaries will soon take place without World War II veterans, huge throngs of aficionados in uniforms and riding vehicles of the time, and tourists soaking up the spectacle, flooded Normandy for the 80th anniversary.\n\n\"It's so historic and we just have to remember the sacrifices of everybody who gave us our freedom,\" said Becky Kraubetz, a Briton now living in Florida whose grandfather served with the British Army during World War II and was captured in Malta.\n\n\"It gives you goosebumps, everything that happened here. Imagine just jumping into the water, freezing cold,\" the 54-year-old said as she gazed across the English Channel, tears in her eyes. \"The bravery, the courage, for people to face that is just unbelievable -- very, very humbled to be here.\"\n\nShe was among a crowd of thousands of people that stretched for several kilometers (miles) along Utah Beach, the westernmost of the D-Day beaches.\n\nIn a quiet spot away from the official ceremonies, France's Christophe Receveur performed his own tribute, unfurling an American flag he had bought on a trip to Pennsylvania to honor those who died on D-Day.\n\n\"To forget them is to let them die all over again,\" the 57-year-old said as he and his daughter, Julie, then carefully refolded the flag into a tight triangle, adding that those now dying in Ukraine fighting the invading Russian army were also on his mind.\n\n\"All these troops came to liberate a country that they didn't know for an ideology -- democracy, freedom -- that is under severe strain now,\" he said.\n\nThe fair-like atmosphere fueled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell, leave open the question of what meaning anniversaries will have once the veterans are gone.\n\nBut at the 80th, they're the VIPs of commemorations across the Normandy coast where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler's defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\n\n\"They really were the golden generation, those 17-, 18-year-old guys doing something so brave,\" said James Baker, a 56-year-old from the Netherlands, reflecting as dawn broke on Utah Beach.\n\nFarther up the coast on Gold Beach, a military bagpiper played at precisely the time that British troops landed there 80 years ago.\n\nThe United Kingdom's King Charles III and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak were among those at a ceremony later in the day to honor the troops who landed there and on Sword Beach, while Prince William and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau joined others at ceremony for the Canadian troops who landed on Juno Beach.\n\nIn his address, the king told the crowd that the world was fortunate that a generation \"did not flinch\" when they were called upon.\n\n\"Our obligation to remember what they stood for and what they achieved for us all can never diminish,\" he said.\n\nSpeaking in French, Charles also paid tribute to the \"unimaginable number\" of French civilians killed in the battle for Normandy, and the bravery and sacrifice of the French Resistance.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron pledged that ''France will never forget'' those who fought to liberate his country.\n\nBiden was to take part in a ceremony later at the American cemetery overlooking Omaha Beach.\n\nThose who traveled to Normandy include women who were among the millions who built bombers, tanks and other weaponry and played other vital World War II roles that were long overshadowed by the combat exploits of men.\n\n\"We weren't doing it for honors and awards. We were doing it to save our country. And we ended up helping save the world,\" said 98-year-old Anna Mae Krier, who worked as a riveter building B-17 and B-29 bombers.\n\nFeted where ever they go in wheelchairs and walking with canes, veterans are using their voices to repeat their message they hope will live eternal: Never forget.\n\n\"To know the amount of people who were killed here, just amazing,\" 98-year-old Allan Chatwin, who served with the U.S. Navy in the Pacific, said as he visited Omaha, the deadliest of the Allied beaches on D-Day.\n\nHe quickly added: \"I don't know that amazing is the word.\" (AP)", "source": {"uri": "8163967469", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "04:40:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T04:40:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T04:39:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "http://sentinelcolorado.com/nation-world/nation/the-sun-rises-over-normandys-beaches-on-d-days-80th-anniversary/", "title": "The sun rises over Normandy's beaches on D-Day's 80th anniversary - Sentinel Colorado", "body": "UTAH BEACH, France | As the sun sets on the D-Day generation, it's rising again over Normandy beaches where soldiers fought and died exactly 80 years ago Thursday, kicking off intense anniversary commemorations against the backdrop of renewed war in Europe, in Ukraine.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans who have pilgrimaged back to France, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine that has dashed hopes that lives and cities wouldn't again be laid to waste in Europe, are making the always poignant anniversaries of the June 6, 1944, Allied landings even more so 80 years on.\n\nAs now-centenarian veterans revisit old memories and fallen comrades buried in Normandy graves, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's presence at D-Day commemorations with world leaders -- including U.S. President Joe Biden -- who are supporting his country's fight against Russia's invasion will inevitably fuse together World War II's awful past with the fraught present on Thursday.\n\nThe break of dawn almost eight decades exactly after Allied troops waded ashore under hails of gunfire on five code-named beaches -- Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword -- will kick off a day of remembrance by Allied nations now standing together again behind Ukraine -- and with World War II ally Russia not invited by host France. It cited Russia's \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks\" for the snub.\n\nWith the dead and wounded on both sides in Ukraine estimated in the hundreds of thousands, commemorations for the more than 4,400 Allied dead on D-Day and many tens of thousands more, including French civilians, killed in the ensuing Battle of Normandy are tinged with concerns that World War II lessons are being lost.\n\n\"There are things worth fighting for,\" said World War II veteran Walter Stitt, who fought in tanks and turns 100 in July, as he visited Omaha Beach this week. \"Although I wish there was another way to do it than to try to kill each other.\"\n\n\"We'll learn one of these days, but I won't be around for that,\" he said.\n\nConscious of the inevitability that major D-Day anniversaries will soon take place without World War II veterans, huge throngs of aficionados in uniforms and riding vehicles of the time, and tourists soaking up the spectacle, have flooded Normandy for the 80th anniversary.\n\n\"They really were the golden generation, those 17-, 18-year-old guys doing something so brave,\" said James Baker, a 56-year-old from the Netherlands, reflecting as dawn broke on Utah Beach.\n\nThe fair-like atmosphere fueled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell, leave open the question of what meaning anniversaries will have once the veterans are gone.\n\nBut at the 80th, they're the VIPs of commemorations across the Normandy coast where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler's defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\n\nThose who traveled to Normandy include women who were among the millions who built bombers, tanks and other weaponry and played other vital World War II roles that were long overshadowed by the combat exploits of men.\n\n\"We weren't doing it for honors and awards. We were doing it to save our country. And we ended up helping save the world,\" said 98-year-old Anna Mae Krier, who worked as a riveter building B-17 and B-29 bombers.\n\nFeted where ever they go in wheelchairs and walking with canes, veterans are using their voices to repeat their message they hope will live eternal: Never forget.\n\n\"To know the amount of people who were killed here, just amazing,\" 98-year-old Allan Chatwin, who served with the U.S. Navy in the Pacific, said as he visited Omaha, the deadliest of the Allied beaches on D-Day.\n\nHe quickly added: \"I don't know that amazing is the word.\"", "source": {"uri": "2024-06-380877541", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:48:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:48:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T07:38:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.weareiowa.com/article/news/nation-world/80th-anniversary-d-day-wwii/507-36656a2e-db47-4e43-9a46-1c0c19e00580", "title": "As the world marks 80th anniversary of D-Day landings, renewed war in Europe is on minds of many", "body": "NORMANDY, France -- Leaders, veterans and visitors from around the world paid tribute Thursday to the D-Day generation in moving ceremonies on and around the Normandy beaches where the Allies landed exactly 80 years ago, with the war in Ukraine on the minds of many and a common message that tyranny cannot be permitted to prevail.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans who have pilgrimaged back to France, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine that has dashed hopes that lives and cities wouldn't again be laid to waste in Europe, are making the poignant anniversary of the June 6, 1944, Allied landings even more so.\n\nThe break of dawn eight decades after Allied troops waded ashore under hails of gunfire on five code-named beaches -- Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword -- kicked off a day of remembrance by Allied nations now standing together again behind Ukraine -- and with World War II ally Russia not invited by host France. It cited Russia's \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks\" for the snub.\n\nWith the dead and wounded on both sides in Ukraine estimated in the hundreds of thousands, commemorations for the more than 4,400 Allied dead on D-Day and many tens of thousands more, including French civilians, killed in the ensuing Battle of Normandy are tinged with concerns that World War II lessons are being lost.\n\n\"There are things worth fighting for,\" said World War II veteran Walter Stitt, who fought in tanks and turns 100 in July, as he visited Omaha Beach this week. \"Although I wish there was another way to do it than to try to kill each other.\"\n\n\"We'll learn one of these days, but I won't be around for that,\" he said.\n\nAs now-centenarian veterans revisit old memories and fallen comrades buried in Normandy graves, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's presence at the D-Day commemorations with world leaders who are supporting Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion -- including U.S. President Joe Biden -- will inevitably fuse together World War II's awful past with the fraught present.\n\nConscious of the inevitability that major D-Day anniversaries will soon take place without World War II veterans, huge throngs of aficionados in uniforms and riding vehicles of the time, and tourists soaking up the spectacle, flooded Normandy for the 80th anniversary.\n\n\"It's so historic and we just have to remember the sacrifices of everybody who gave us our freedom,\" said Becky Kraubetz, a Briton now living in Florida whose grandfather served with the British Army during World War II and was captured in Malta.\n\n\"It gives you goosebumps, everything that happened here. Imagine just jumping into the water, freezing cold,\" the 54-year-old said as she gazed across the English Channel, tears in her eyes. \"The bravery, the courage, for people to face that is just unbelievable -- very, very humbled to be here.\"\n\nShe was among a crowd of thousands of people that stretched for several kilometers (miles) along Utah Beach, the westernmost of the D-Day beaches.\n\nIn a quiet spot away from the official ceremonies, France's Christophe Receveur performed his own tribute, unfurling an American flag he had bought on a trip to Pennsylvania to honor those who died on D-Day.\n\n\"To forget them is to let them die all over again,\" the 57-year-old said as he and his daughter, Julie, then carefully refolded the flag into a tight triangle, adding that those now dying in Ukraine fighting the invading Russian army were also on his mind.\n\n\"All these troops came to liberate a country that they didn't know for an ideology -- democracy, freedom -- that is under severe strain now,\" he said.\n\nThe fair-like atmosphere fueled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell, leave open the question of what meaning anniversaries will have once the veterans are gone.\n\nBut at the 80th, they're the VIPs of commemorations across the Normandy coast where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler's defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\n\n\"They really were the golden generation, those 17-, 18-year-old guys doing something so brave,\" said James Baker, a 56-year-old from the Netherlands, reflecting as dawn broke on Utah Beach.\n\nFarther up the coast on Gold Beach, a military bagpiper played at precisely the time that British troops landed there 80 years ago.\n\nThe United Kingdom's King Charles III and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak were among those at a ceremony later in the day to honor the troops who landed there and on Sword Beach, while Prince William and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau joined others at ceremony for the Canadian troops who landed on Juno Beach.\n\nIn his address, the king told the crowd that the world was fortunate that a generation \"did not flinch\" when they were called upon.\n\n\"Our obligation to remember what they stood for and what they achieved for us all can never diminish,\" he said.\n\nSpeaking in French, Charles also paid tribute to the \"unimaginable number\" of French civilians killed in the battle for Normandy, and the bravery and sacrifice of the French Resistance.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron pledged that ''France will never forget'' those who fought to liberate his country.\n\nBiden was to take part in a ceremony later at the American cemetery overlooking Omaha Beach.\n\nThose who traveled to Normandy include women who were among the millions who built bombers, tanks and other weaponry and played other vital World War II roles that were long overshadowed by the combat exploits of men.\n\n\"We weren't doing it for honors and awards. We were doing it to save our country. And we ended up helping save the world,\" said 98-year-old Anna Mae Krier, who worked as a riveter building B-17 and B-29 bombers.\n\nFeted where ever they go in wheelchairs and walking with canes, veterans are using their voices to repeat their message they hope will live eternal: Never forget.\n\n\"To know the amount of people who were killed here, just amazing,\" 98-year-old Allan Chatwin, who served with the U.S. Navy in the Pacific, said as he visited Omaha, the deadliest of the Allied beaches on D-Day.\n\nHe quickly added: \"I don't know that amazing is the word.\"", "source": {"uri": "weareiowa.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Local 5 - weareiowa.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Russian invasion of Ukraine"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normandy_landings", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Normandy landings"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "8163856792", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "02:47:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T02:47:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T02:45:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13500087/The-costs-World-War-II-war-Ukraine-fuse-Allies-remember-D-Day-without-Russia.html", "title": "The costs of World War II and the war in Ukraine fuse as Allies...", "body": "UTAH BEACH, France (AP) - As the sun sets on the D-Day generation, it will rise again Thursday over the Normandy beaches where the waves long ago washed away the blood and boot-steps of its soldiers, but where their exploits that helped end Adolf Hitler's tyranny are being remembered by the next generations, seeing war again in Europe, in Ukraine.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans who have pilgrimaged back to France, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine that has dashed hopes that lives and cities wouldn't again be laid to waste in Europe, are making the always poignant anniversaries of the June 6, 1944, Allied landings even more so 80 years on.\n\nAs now-centenarian veterans revisit old memories and fallen comrades buried in Normandy graves, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's presence at D-Day commemorations with world leaders - including U.S. President Joe Biden - who are supporting his country's fight against Russia's invasion will inevitably fuse together World War II's awful past with the fraught present on Thursday.\n\nThe break of dawn almost eight decades exactly after Allied troops waded ashore under hails of gunfire on five code-named beaches - Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword - will kick off a day of remembrance by Allied nations now standing together again behind Ukraine - and with World War II ally Russia not invited by host France. It cited Russia's \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks\" for the snub.\n\nWith the dead and wounded on both sides in Ukraine estimated in the hundreds of thousands, commemorations for the more than 4,400 Allied dead on D-Day and many tens of thousands more, including French civilians, killed in the ensuing Battle of Normandy are tinged with concerns that World War II lessons are being lost.\n\n\"There are things worth fighting for,\" said World War II veteran Walter Stitt, who fought in tanks and turns 100 in July, as he visited Omaha Beach this week. \"Although I wish there was another way to do it than to try to kill each other.\"\n\nAmerican WWII veteran Bill Wall throws roses into the water during a wreath-laying ceremony at Utah Beach, Wednesday, June 5, 2024 at Utah Beach, Normandy,. World War II veterans from across the United States as well as Britain and Canada are in Normandy this week to mark 80 years since the D-Day landings that helped lead to Hitler's defeat. (AP Photo/Jeremias Gonzalez)\n\n\"We\u00b4ll learn one of these days, but I won\u00b4t be around for that,\" he said.\n\nConscious of the inevitability that major D-Day anniversaries will soon take place without World War II veterans, huge throngs of aficionados in uniforms and riding vehicles of the time, and tourists soaking up the spectacle, have flooded Normandy for the 80th anniversary.\n\nThe fair-like atmosphere fueled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell, leave open the question of what meaning anniversaries will have once the veterans are gone.\n\nBut at the 80th, they're the VIPs of commemorations across the Normandy coast where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler\u00b4s defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\n\nThose who traveled to Normandy include women who were among the millions who built bombers, tanks and other weaponry and played other vital World War II roles that were long overshadowed by the combat exploits of men.\n\n\"We weren\u00b4t doing it for honors and awards. We were doing it to save our country. And we ended up helping save the world,\" said 98-year-old Anna Mae Krier, who worked as a riveter building B-17 and B-29 bombers.\n\nFeted where ever they go in wheelchairs and walking with canes, veterans are using their voices to repeat their message they hope will live eternal: Never forget.\n\n\"To know the amount of people who were killed here, just amazing,\" 98-year-old Allan Chatwin, who served with the U.S. Navy in the Pacific, said as he visited Omaha, the deadliest of the Allied beaches on D-Day.\n\nHe quickly added: \"I don't know that amazing is the word.\"\n\nAmerican WWII veterans Bill Wall, left, and Bob Tedesco attend a ceremony on Omaha Beach, Tuesday, June 4, 2024 in Normandy. World War II veterans from across the United States as well as Britain and Canada are in Normandy this week to mark 80 years since the D-Day landings that helped lead to Hitler's defeat. (AP Photo/Jeremias Gonzalez)\n\nRoses lay ashore during a wreath-laying ceremony at Utah Beach, Wednesday, June 5, 2024 at Utah Beach, Normandy,. World War II veterans from across the United States as well as Britain and Canada are in Normandy this week to mark 80 years since the D-Day landings that helped lead to Hitler's defeat. (AP Photo/Jeremias Gonzalez)\n\nFILE - U.S. soldiers stand on the remains of a house as they inspect damage in Carentan, in the Normandy region of France, June 15, 1944. The 80th anniversary this week of D-Day is a mixed bag of emotions for French survivors of the Battle of Normandy. They remain eternally grateful for their liberation from Nazi occupation in World War II but cannot forget its steep cost in French lives. {"uri": "8164076169", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "06:14:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T06:14:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T06:13:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/sun-rises-over-normandys-beaches-as-world-gets-ready-to-observe-d-days-80th-anniversary-13779374.html", "title": "Sun rises over Normandy's beaches as world gets ready to observe D-Day's 80th anniversary", "body": "Utah Beach, France: As the sun sets on the D-Day generation, it's rising again over Normandy beaches where soldiers fought and died exactly 80 years ago Thursday, kicking off intense anniversary commemorations against the backdrop of renewed war in Europe, in Ukraine.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans who have pilgrimaged back to France, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine that has dashed hopes that lives and cities wouldn't again be laid to waste in Europe, are making the always poignant anniversaries of the June 6, 1944, Allied landings even more so 80 years on.\n\nAs now-centenarian veterans revisit old memories and fallen comrades buried in Normandy graves, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's presence at D-Day commemorations with world leaders -- including US President Joe Biden -- who are supporting his country's fight against Russia's invasion will inevitably fuse together World War II's awful past with the fraught present on Thursday.\n\nThe break of dawn almost eight decades exactly after Allied troops waded ashore under hails of gunfire on five code-named beaches -- Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword -- will kick off a day of remembrance by Allied nations now standing together again behind Ukraine -- and with World War II ally Russia not invited by host France. It cited Russia's \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks\" for the snub.\n\nWith the dead and wounded on both sides in Ukraine estimated in the hundreds of thousands, commemorations for the more than 4,400 Allied dead on D-Day and many tens of thousands more, including French civilians, killed in the ensuing Battle of Normandy are tinged with concerns that World War II lessons are being lost.\n\n\"There are things worth fighting for,\" said World War II veteran Walter Stitt, who fought in tanks and turns 100 in July, as he visited Omaha Beach this week. \"Although I wish there was another way to do it than to try to kill each other.\"\n\n\"We'll learn one of these days, but I won't be around for that,\" he said.\n\nConscious of the inevitability that major D-Day anniversaries will soon take place without World War II veterans, huge throngs of aficionados in uniforms and riding vehicles of the time, and tourists soaking up the spectacle, have flooded Normandy for the 80th anniversary.\n\n\"It's so historic and we just have to remember the sacrifices of everybody who gave us our freedom,\" said Becky Kraubetz, a Briton now living in Florida whose grandfather served with the British Army during World War II and was captured in Malta.\n\n\"It gives you goosebumps, everything that happened here. Imagine just jumping into the water, freezing cold,\" the 54-year-old said as she gazed across the English Channel, tears in her eyes. \"The bravery, the courage, for people to face that is just unbelievable -- very, very humbled to be here.\"\n\nThe fair-like atmosphere fuelled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell, leave open the question of what meaning anniversaries will have once the veterans are gone.\n\nBut at the 80th, they're the VIPs of commemorations across the Normandy coast where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler's defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\n\n\"They really were the golden generation, those 17-, 18-year-old guys doing something so brave,\" said James Baker, a 56-year-old from the Netherlands, reflecting as dawn broke on Utah Beach.\n\nThose who travelled to Normandy include women who were among the millions who built bombers, tanks and other weaponry and played other vital World War II roles that were long overshadowed by the combat exploits of men.\n\n\"We weren't doing it for honours and awards. We were doing it to save our country. And we ended up helping save the world,\" said 98-year-old Anna Mae Krier, who worked as a riveter building B-17 and B-29 bombers.\n\nFeted where ever they go in wheelchairs and walking with canes, veterans are using their voices to repeat their message they hope will live eternal: Never forget.\n\n\"To know the amount of people who were killed here, just amazing,\" 98-year-old Allan Chatwin, who served with the U.S. Navy in the Pacific, said as he visited Omaha, the deadliest of the Allied beaches on D-Day.\n\nHe quickly added: \"I don't know that amazing is the word.\"", "source": {"uri": "8164641410", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:13:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:13:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:11:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://lethbridgeherald.com/news/world-news/2024/06/06/as-the-world-marks-80th-anniversary-of-dday-landings-renewed-war-in-europe-is-on-minds-of-many/", "title": "As the world marks 80th anniversary of D-Day landings, renewed war in Europe is on minds of many", "body": "UTAH BEACH, France (AP) - Twelve U.S. and British World War II veterans were given Legion of Honor awards by French President Emmanuel Macron on Thursday, the 80th anniversary of D-Day.\n\nMacron pinned medals on the 11 Americans and one Briton at a ceremony at the American Cemetery overlooking Omaha Beach, attended by U.S. President Joe Biden.\n\n\"You came here because the free world needed each and every one of you, and you answered the call,\"\u00b3 Macron said. \"\u00b3You came here to make France a free nation. You're back here today at home, if I may say.\"\u009d\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nUTAH BEACH, France (AP) - Leaders, veterans and visitors from around the world paid tribute Thursday to the D-Day generation in moving ceremonies on and around the Normandy beaches where the Allies landed exactly 80 years ago, with the war in Ukraine on the minds of many and a common message that tyranny cannot be permitted to prevail.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans who have pilgrimaged back to France, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine that has dashed hopes that lives and cities wouldn't again be laid to waste in Europe, are making the poignant anniversary of the June 6, 1944, Allied landings even more so.\n\nThe break of dawn eight decades after Allied troops waded ashore under hails of gunfire on five code-named beaches - Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword - kicked off a day of remembrance by Allied nations now standing together again behind Ukraine - and with World War II ally Russia not invited by host France. It cited Russia's \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks\"\u009d for the snub.\n\nWith the dead and wounded on both sides in Ukraine estimated in the hundreds of thousands, commemorations for the more than 4,400 Allied dead on D-Day and many tens of thousands more, including French civilians, killed in the ensuing Battle of Normandy are tinged with concerns that World War II lessons are being lost.\n\n\"There are things worth fighting for,\"\u009d said World War II veteran Walter Stitt, who fought in tanks and turns 100 in July, as he visited Omaha Beach this week. \"Although I wish there was another way to do it than to try to kill each other.\"\u009d\n\n\"We'll learn one of these days, but I won't be around for that,\"\u009d he said.\n\nAs now-centenarian veterans revisit old memories and fallen comrades buried in Normandy graves, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's presence at the D-Day commemorations with world leaders who are supporting Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion - including U.S. President Joe Biden - will inevitably fuse together World War II's awful past with the fraught present.\n\nConscious of the inevitability that major D-Day anniversaries will soon take place without World War II veterans, huge throngs of aficionados in uniforms and riding vehicles of the time, and tourists soaking up the spectacle, flooded Normandy for the 80th anniversary.\n\n\"It's so historic and we just have to remember the sacrifices of everybody who gave us our freedom,\"\u009d said Becky Kraubetz, a Briton now living in Florida whose grandfather served with the British Army during World War II and was captured in Malta.\n\n\"It gives you goosebumps, everything that happened here. Imagine just jumping into the water, freezing cold,\"\u009d the 54-year-old said as she gazed across the English Channel, tears in her eyes. \"The bravery, the courage, for people to face that is just unbelievable - very, very humbled to be here.\"\u009d\n\nShe was among a crowd of thousands of people that stretched for several kilometers (miles) along Utah Beach, the westernmost of the D-Day beaches.\n\nIn a quiet spot away from the official ceremonies, France's Christophe Receveur performed his own tribute, unfurling an American flag he had bought on a trip to Pennsylvania to honor those who died on D-Day.\n\n\"To forget them is to let them die all over again,\"\u009d the 57-year-old said as he and his daughter, Julie, then carefully refolded the flag into a tight triangle, adding that those now dying in Ukraine fighting the invading Russian army were also on his mind.\n\n\"All these troops came to liberate a country that they didn't know for an ideology - democracy, freedom - that is under severe strain now,\"\u009d he said.\n\nThe fair-like atmosphere fueled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell, leave open the question of what meaning anniversaries will have once the veterans are gone.\n\nBut at the 80th, they're the VIPs of commemorations across the Normandy coast where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler's defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\n\n\"They really were the golden generation, those 17-, 18-year-old guys doing something so brave,\"\u009d said James Baker, a 56-year-old from the Netherlands, reflecting as dawn broke on Utah Beach.\n\nFarther up the coast on Gold Beach, a military bagpiper played at precisely the time that British troops landed there 80 years ago.\n\nThe United Kingdom's King Charles III and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak were among those at a ceremony later in the day to honor the troops who landed there and on Sword Beach, while Prince William and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau joined others at ceremony for the Canadian troops who landed on Juno Beach.\n\nIn his address, the king told the crowd that the world was fortunate that a generation \"did not flinch\" when they were called upon.\n\n\"Our obligation to remember what they stood for and what they achieved for us all can never diminish,\"\u009d he said.\n\nSpeaking in French, Charles also paid tribute to the \"unimaginable number\"\u009d of French civilians killed in the battle for Normandy, and the bravery and sacrifice of the French Resistance.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron pledged that \"\u00b3France will never forget\"\u00b3 those who fought to liberate his country.\n\nBiden was to take part in a ceremony later at the American cemetery overlooking Omaha Beach.\n\nThose who traveled to Normandy include women who were among the millions who built bombers, tanks and other weaponry and played other vital World War II roles that were long overshadowed by the combat exploits of men.\n\n\"We weren't doing it for honors and awards. We were doing it to save our country. And we ended up helping save the world,\"\u009d said 98-year-old Anna Mae Krier, who worked as a riveter building B-17 and B-29 bombers.\n\nFeted where ever they go in wheelchairs and walking with canes, veterans are using their voices to repeat their message they hope will live eternal: Never forget.\n\n\"To know the amount of people who were killed here, just amazing,\"\u009d 98-year-old Allan Chatwin, who served with the U.S. Navy in the Pacific, said as he visited Omaha, the deadliest of the Allied beaches on D-Day.\n\nHe quickly added: \"I don't know that amazing is the word.\"\u009d", "source": {"uri": "lethbridgeherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Lethbridge Herald - News and Sports from around Lethbridge"}, "authors": [{"uri": those now dying in Ukraine fighting the invading Russian army were also on his mind.\n\n\"All these troops came to liberate a country that they didn't know for an ideology -- democracy, freedom -- later.\n\n\"They really were the golden generation, those 17-, 18-year-old guys doing something so brave,\" said James Baker, a 56-year-old from the Netherlands, reflecting as dawn broke on Utah
