{"uri": "8164614809", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "11:56:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T11:56:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T11:55:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/news/nation-world/d-day-80th-anniversary-world-war-ii-veterans-normandy-beaches/article_a0e2fae9-b234-5a7b-92da-3f8653be0f80.html", "title": "D-Day's 80th anniversary brings World War II veterans back to the beaches of Normandy", "body": "World War II veterans are joining heads of state and others on the beaches of Normandy to commemorate the 80th anniversary of D-Day\n\nWorld War II veterans joined heads of state and others Thursday on the beaches of Normandy to commemorate the 80th anniversary of D-Day.\n\nThe Allied invasion, which began on June 6, 1944, led to the defeat of the Nazis and the end of the war. The assault began with Allied aircraft bombing German defenses in Normandy, followed by around 1,200 aircraft that carried airborne troops. As dawn broke, Allied forces started bombing German coastal defenses and shortly after that vessels began putting troops ashore on five codenamed beaches: Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword. By the end of the day, nearly 160,000 Allied troops had landed in Normandy, although there were thousands of casualties.\n\nFew witnesses to history's biggest amphibious invasion remain alive today. Here's the latest:\n\nPRINCE WILLIAM PRAISES CANADIAN TROOPS IN NORMANDY People are also reading... Father of Baraboo High School graduate blocks superintendent from shaking daughter's hand Biker suffers injuries in fall on Grandad Bluff in La Crosse THE WAY IT WAS: Myrick Park Zoo, 3 June 2004 Steve Cahalan: Fat Pat's Brewery opens in downtown Spring Grove La Crosse board denies marshland-specific camping ban Complaint: Stolen debit card used to make fraudulent purchases in La Crosse Structure fire in Onalaska causes major damage to building High school cross country: Onalaska junior makes college decision Exotic dance club in Monroe County destroyed by fire 36-year-old Ettrick man identified as victim of Trempealeau County homicide Steve Cahalan: Trading card store opens in Valley View Mall Onalaska man faces charges after reckless driving incident on Highway 53 Play Grounds of La Crosse set to open largest indoor playground in Wisconsin in November Police reportedly uncover substantial drug stash in La Crosse traffic stop WIAA state track and field notebook: La Crosse Logan's Julie Yang caps career with three medals\n\nJUNO BEACH, France -- Prince William has praised the bravery and sacrifice of Canadian troops as he addressed a D-Day anniversary ceremony on Juno Beach.\n\nThe royal was joined by Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal and Canadian D-Day veterans.\n\nSome 14,000 Canadians were part of the 150,000 Allied troops who landed or parachuted into Normandy in 1944.\n\n\"Far from home they stormed these very sand dunes behind me, shoulder to shoulder with thousands of British troops,\" William said.\n\nAddressing veterans at the ceremony, the royal added: \"Thank you for our freedom, and thank you for your service.\"\n\nNation & World He saw the horrors of Dachau. Now, this WWII veteran warns against Holocaust denial ASSOCIATED PRESS PRESIDENT BIDEN MEETS WITH AMERICAN VETERANS\n\nCOLLEVILLE-SUR-MER, France -- U.S. President Joe Biden met with American veterans of D-Day as he marked the invasion's 80th anniversary.\n\nVeterans who could stand were helped out of wheelchairs to pose for photos with the president and first lady Jill Biden. One hugged Biden, another saluted. When Biden learned it was the birthday of one of the veterans, he led the audience in singing 'Happy Birthday.'\n\nThe first lady clutched the arm of another veteran, Robert Gibson, to help him stand next to Biden as they shook hands. \"Don't get old,\" the 100-year-old man joked to the 81-year-old president, who was a toddler when D-Day took place.\n\nSteve Spielberg and Tom Hanks, the Hollywood heavyweights behind movies and television shows about World War II, were nearby.\n\nKING CHARLES AND QUEEN CAMILLA LEAD D-DAY COMMEMORATIONS AT NEW MEMORIAL IN FRANCE\n\nVER-SUR-MER, France -- King Charles III and Queen Camilla led commemorations at the new British Normandy Memorial in Ver-sur-Mer.\n\nCamilla wiped away a tear as actor Martin Freeman read words by 99-year-old D-Day veteran Joe Mines, recalling that \"I was 19 when I landed, but I was still a boy. I don't care what people say, I wasn't a man, I was a boy. And I didn't have any idea of war and killing.\"\n\nPrime Minister Rishi Sunak and Labour Party leader Keir Starmer took a break from campaigning for Britain's July 4 election to travel to France for the ceremony.\n\nSunak paid tribute to veterans, saying their \"actions freed a continent and built a better world.\"\n\n\"You risked everything and we owe you everything,\" he said. \"We cannot possibly hope to repay that debt but we can and we must pledge never to forget.\"\n\nWelsh singer Tom Jones, 83, sang his song \"I Won't Crumble With You If You Fall,\" before the king addressed the audience in French and English.\n\nCharles said that while the number of living veterans was dwindling, \"our obligation to remember what they stood for and what they achieved for us all can never diminish.\"\n\nSpeaking in French, Charles paid tribute to the \"unimaginable number\" of French civilians killed in the battle for Normandy, and the bravery and sacrifice of the French Resistance.\n\nMAN HONORS A GRANDFATHER HE NEVER KNEW, AN OFFICER WHO SMUGGLED HIMSELF ON A LANDING CRAFT\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- Among the thousands who flocked to D-Day beach Utah was the grandson of an American colonel who smuggled himself aboard a landing craft so he could join his men in the first waves of the June 6, 1944, invasion.\n\nJohn Reistrup, 55, never met his grandfather, Eugene M. Caffey, who died in 1961. Coming back to Utah for the 80th anniversary was his way of carrying \"the torch for someone you never met that had such an impact on so many lives.\"\n\nA plaque at the beach that honors his grandfather says the colonel led the 19,500 men of the 1st Engineer Special Brigade tasked on that fateful day with the logistics of the landing on Utah, one of five invasion beaches.\n\nNot scheduled to land until 0900, Caffey, a 49-year-old father of nine, had smuggled himself, with no equipment except an empty rifle, aboard an 8th Infantry landing craft. En route he managed to load his rifle by taking up a collection of one bullet each from eight infantrymen. He arrived ashore very early in the assault, Reistrup said.\n\n\"No officers were allowed on the first waves of the landing but he said, 'Hell, no, I'm going with my guys.'\"\n\nA Nazi bunker captured on the beach then became his grandfather's office, he said. Caffey's portrait hangs there, inside, to this day.\n\nForging ahead into fire on D-Day \"has got to be the greatest courage you could ever have,\" said Reistrup, who has visited Normandy about 10 times since his first visit as a kid in 1974.\n\nNation & World Jewish veteran from London prepares to commemorate 80th anniversary of D-Day landings DANICA KIRKA Associated Press 4 min to read THOUSANDS OF PEOPLE DOT FRANCE'S UTAH BEACH FOR D-DAY COMMEMORATIONS\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- Thousands of people, including many people in World War II-era uniforms, were stretched for several kilometers (miles) along Utah Beach ahead of commemorations marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings.\n\nUtah was one of the five landing beaches along the coast of Normandy where Allied troops landed on June 6, 2024. Utah and Omaha were taken -- at the cost of hundreds of lives -- by American forces, with the others stormed by troops from Britain and Canada, also killing many hundreds, plus others from France.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe long stretch of the Normandy coast is where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler's defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\n\nA fair-like atmosphere is fueled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell.\n\nSurviving veterans, who are around 100 years old now, are the VIPs of the day's events.\n\nNation & World At 100, this vet says the 'greatest generation' moniker fits 'because we saved the world' ASSOCIATED PRESS 2 min to read 'FREEDOM COSTS,' DENMARK'S PRIME MINISTER SAYS AS SHE MARKS D-DAY'S 80TH ANNIVERSARY\n\nCOPENHAGEN, Denmark -- Denmark's prime minister said that this year's observances of the D-Day landings, which come as Russia is at war against Ukraine, are a reminder that there is a price for defending freedom.\n\n\"From D-Day we have learned that freedom costs,\" Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said in a statement as she headed to Normandy for ceremonies marking the 80th anniversary of the Allied landings.\n\n\"Eighty years later, Europe once again finds itself at a fateful moment. Where freedom is once again being fought for on our own continent,\" she said, \"against an aggressive and brutal enemy who will dictate country borders with brute force and leave a trail of death and destruction.\"\n\nIMAGINING THE HORROR AND CELEBRATING FREEDOM\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- Because freedom is worth celebrating and passing on to children, too, Alexandra Hamon, 35, drank champagne and shared the sunrise with her boys, Karl and Neils, both 13, as the day dawned Thursday over the beaches where Allied soldiers landed on D-Day.\n\nThe family was among a crowd several thousands strong that stretched for kilometers along Utah beach -- one of the five beaches along the coast of Normandy where Allied troops landed. Utah and Omaha were taken -- at the cost of hundreds of lives -- by American forces, with the others stormed by troops from Britain and Canada, also killing many hundreds, plus others from France. The other code-named beaches are Juno, Sword and Gold.\n\nKarl sat perched on the hood of their 1943 Dodge truck, lovingly restored by her husband, Enogat, as the family from Saint Malo, a French coastal city that was badly damaged in major fighting about two months after D-Day, stared out across the English Channel.\n\nThe waters Thursday were still and peaceful -- unlike on that fateful day that helped change the course of WWII and precipitate Adolf Hitler's downfall 11 months later.\n\n\"It's indescribable, just imagining the chaos. Now it's peaceful, almost festive, we try to imagine but I think it's unimaginable,\" she said.\n\n\"You think of all those guys, everything they went through,\" she added of the fast-dwindling D-Day veterans. \"They say they aren't heroes. But they are, they are. Those guys really should never die. I imagine the boats, the guys arriving, the sounds. It must have been horrible, yes, horrible.\"\n\nKEEPING ALIVE THE MEMORY OF SOLDIERS 'WHO DIED FOR OUR FREEDOM'\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- As the rising sun took the night's chill off Utah Beach, Christophe Receveur, 57, from Thionville in eastern France, unfurled a Stars and Stripes he bought in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, six months ago specifically to honor the Americans who fell on D-Day.\n\n\"To keep alive the memory of the soldiers who died for our freedom,\" he said. \"To forget them is to let them die all over again.\"\n\nReceveur and his daughter, Julie, 28, carefully folded the flag into a tight triangle after their quiet, reflective homage on an empty stretch of the beach, busy with hundreds of people strung out along the sands.\n\nReceveur said the Ukraine war was on his mind, too, as he honored the fallen of WWII. His great grandfather fought in WWI, his grandfather was a prisoner of war in WWII, and his father was a veteran of France's war in former North African colony Algeria.\n\n\"I don't want our freedom, for our kids, our grandkids, to be hit by ... I don't want to say a madman,\" referring to Russian President Vladimir Putin. \"So a lot of respect for these people who died and for those who are still dying,\" he said of the WWII dead and those in Ukraine.\n\nHe said the D-Day sacrifices have to be remembered. \"Lots of emotion that all these troops came to liberate a country that they didn't know for an ideology -- democracy, freedom -- that is under severe strain now.\"\n\n'WE JUST HAVE TO REMEMBER THE SACRIFICES'\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- As the golden sun pierced low clouds over the seas that were thick with landing craft approaching Normandy on D-Day, Becky Kraubetz peered across the English Channel toward her native Britain, her eyes filled with tears as she thought about the scene 80 years ago.\n\n\"It's so historic and we just have to remember the sacrifices of everybody who gave us our freedom,\" said Kraubetz, whose grandfather served with the British Army during World War II and was captured in Malta.\n\n\"It gives you goosebumps, everything that happened here. Imagine just jumping into the water, freezing cold,\" said the 54-year-old who now lives in Florida, as the rays of the morning sun started to warm the hundreds of people who'd waited through the night's chill for dawn's break.\n\n\"The bravery, the courage, for people to face that is just unbelievable -- very, very humbled to be here.\"\n\nTHE SUN RISES OVER NORMANDY BEACHES AS THE WORLD REMEMBERS D-DAY\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- As the sun sets on the D-Day generation, it's rising again over Normandy beaches where soldiers fought and died exactly 80 years ago, kicking off intense anniversary commemorations Thursday against the backdrop of renewed war in Europe, in Ukraine.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, make this anniversary particularly meaningful, mixing poignant remembrances for D-Day sacrifices with an Allied show of solidarity for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, among the guests.\n\nBut host France hasn't invited World War II ally Russia, citing its \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks.\"\n\nHUNDREDS GATHER AT DAWN AT UTAH BEACH TO MARK D-DAY'S 80TH ANNIVERSARY\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- Hundreds of people, some in WWII-era uniforms, arrived before dawn to stretch out across the now peaceful sands of Utah Beach, one of the five Allied landing zones on D-Day where troops waded into cold seas through hails of fire exactly 80 years ago.\n\n\"It's our way of paying homage, and better understanding what really happened in the 1944 landings,\" said Dimitri Picot, a 33-year-old from the nearby Normandy town of Carentan who works as a rat and pest catcher.\n\nPicot said he often dives on a wrecked ship that was hit and exploded, its wreckage visible Thursday as night gave way to day. Growing up amid the June 6, 1944, landing zones, he said he has become accustomed to seeing walls still pockmarked by bullets, shrapnel and other reminders of that fateful day.\n\nBut on the 80th anniversary \"to think that they liberated us\" hammered home the emotion, he said.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9628959", "eventUri": "eng-9628959", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2004-06-03", "textStart": 1185, "textEnd": 1196}, {"amb": {"uri": "8164607708", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "11:51:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T11:51:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T11:51:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://journalstar.com/news/nation-world/d-day-80th-anniversary-world-war-ii-veterans-normandy-beaches/article_93069152-5580-53a1-a57a-baebd5d7ce13.html", "title": "D-Day's 80th anniversary brings World War II veterans back to the beaches of Normandy", "body": "World War II veterans are joining heads of state and others on the beaches of Normandy to commemorate the 80th anniversary of D-Day\n\nWorld War II veterans joined heads of state and others Thursday on the beaches of Normandy to commemorate the 80th anniversary of D-Day.\n\nThe Allied invasion, which began on June 6, 1944, led to the defeat of the Nazis and the end of the war. The assault began with Allied aircraft bombing German defenses in Normandy, followed by around 1,200 aircraft that carried airborne troops. As dawn broke, Allied forces started bombing German coastal defenses and shortly after that vessels began putting troops ashore on five codenamed beaches: Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword. By the end of the day, nearly 160,000 Allied troops had landed in Normandy, although there were thousands of casualties.\n\nFew witnesses to history's biggest amphibious invasion remain alive today. Here's the latest:\n\nPRINCE WILLIAM PRAISES CANADIAN TROOPS IN NORMANDY People are also reading... Woman believed to be dead turns out to be alive at Lincoln funeral home, officials say New inclusive playground coming to Omaha's Zorinsky Lake Park Lincoln man gets max time for random attack downtown that killed beloved 55-year-old High-priced lots earmarked for villas hit the market at The Knolls in southeast Lincoln As Republicans deride Trump verdict, Nebraska Rep. Flood calls for 'respect of the rule of law' Lincoln man's murder case begins with dramatic video of his father dying 'Still a whirlwind' -- Fresh off success on 'The Voice,' Olesen looks forward to Lincoln shows Woman mistakenly pronounced dead at Waverly nursing home dies at Lincoln hospital Falls City woman dies in single-vehicle crash in Sarpy County Video shows shooting outside downtown Lincoln bar; no charges filed against security guard Nebraska volleyball post-spring series: Outside hitter the position with the most storylines South Lincoln house fire does $2.75 million in damage, officials say 'We were able to respond': Niagara starts fast, but Nebraska baseball counters to stay alive Council votes to update what vehicles are allowed on Lincoln hiker-biker trails Lincoln hookah bar's liquor license suspended after shooting, repeated security issues\n\nJUNO BEACH, France -- Prince William has praised the bravery and sacrifice of Canadian troops as he addressed a D-Day anniversary ceremony on Juno Beach.\n\nThe royal was joined by Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal and Canadian D-Day veterans.\n\nSome 14,000 Canadians were part of the 150,000 Allied troops who landed or parachuted into Normandy in 1944.\n\n\"Far from home they stormed these very sand dunes behind me, shoulder to shoulder with thousands of British troops,\" William said.\n\nAddressing veterans at the ceremony, the royal added: \"Thank you for our freedom, and thank you for your service.\"\n\nNation & World He saw the horrors of Dachau. Now, this WWII veteran warns against Holocaust denial ASSOCIATED PRESS PRESIDENT BIDEN MEETS WITH AMERICAN VETERANS\n\nCOLLEVILLE-SUR-MER, France -- U.S. President Joe Biden met with American veterans of D-Day as he marked the invasion's 80th anniversary.\n\nVeterans who could stand were helped out of wheelchairs to pose for photos with the president and first lady Jill Biden. One hugged Biden, another saluted. When Biden learned it was the birthday of one of the veterans, he led the audience in singing 'Happy Birthday.'\n\nThe first lady clutched the arm of another veteran, Robert Gibson, to help him stand next to Biden as they shook hands. \"Don't get old,\" the 100-year-old man joked to the 81-year-old president, who was a toddler when D-Day took place.\n\nSteve Spielberg and Tom Hanks, the Hollywood heavyweights behind movies and television shows about World War II, were nearby.\n\nKING CHARLES AND QUEEN CAMILLA LEAD D-DAY COMMEMORATIONS AT NEW MEMORIAL IN FRANCE\n\nVER-SUR-MER, France -- King Charles III and Queen Camilla led commemorations at the new British Normandy Memorial in Ver-sur-Mer.\n\nCamilla wiped away a tear as actor Martin Freeman read words by 99-year-old D-Day veteran Joe Mines, recalling that \"I was 19 when I landed, but I was still a boy. I don't care what people say, I wasn't a man, I was a boy. And I didn't have any idea of war and killing.\"\n\nPrime Minister Rishi Sunak and Labour Party leader Keir Starmer took a break from campaigning for Britain's July 4 election to travel to France for the ceremony.\n\nSunak paid tribute to veterans, saying their \"actions freed a continent and built a better world.\"\n\n\"You risked everything and we owe you everything,\" he said. \"We cannot possibly hope to repay that debt but we can and we must pledge never to forget.\"\n\nWelsh singer Tom Jones, 83, sang his song \"I Won't Crumble With You If You Fall,\" before the king addressed the audience in French and English.\n\nCharles said that while the number of living veterans was dwindling, \"our obligation to remember what they stood for and what they achieved for us all can never diminish.\"\n\nSpeaking in French, Charles paid tribute to the \"unimaginable number\" of French civilians killed in the battle for Normandy, and the bravery and sacrifice of the French Resistance.\n\nMAN HONORS A GRANDFATHER HE NEVER KNEW, AN OFFICER WHO SMUGGLED HIMSELF ON A LANDING CRAFT\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- Among the thousands who flocked to D-Day beach Utah was the grandson of an American colonel who smuggled himself aboard a landing craft so he could join his men in the first waves of the June 6, 1944, invasion.\n\nJohn Reistrup, 55, never met his grandfather, Eugene M. Caffey, who died in 1961. Coming back to Utah for the 80th anniversary was his way of carrying \"the torch for someone you never met that had such an impact on so many lives.\"\n\nA plaque at the beach that honors his grandfather says the colonel led the 19,500 men of the 1st Engineer Special Brigade tasked on that fateful day with the logistics of the landing on Utah, one of five invasion beaches.\n\nNot scheduled to land until 0900, Caffey, a 49-year-old father of nine, had smuggled himself, with no equipment except an empty rifle, aboard an 8th Infantry landing craft. En route he managed to load his rifle by taking up a collection of one bullet each from eight infantrymen. He arrived ashore very early in the assault, Reistrup said.\n\n\"No officers were allowed on the first waves of the landing but he said, 'Hell, no, I'm going with my guys.'\"\n\nA Nazi bunker captured on the beach then became his grandfather's office, he said. Caffey's portrait hangs there, inside, to this day.\n\nForging ahead into fire on D-Day \"has got to be the greatest courage you could ever have,\" said Reistrup, who has visited Normandy about 10 times since his first visit as a kid in 1974.\n\nNation & World Jewish veteran from London prepares to commemorate 80th anniversary of D-Day landings DANICA KIRKA Associated Press 4 min to read THOUSANDS OF PEOPLE DOT FRANCE'S UTAH BEACH FOR D-DAY COMMEMORATIONS\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- Thousands of people, including many people in World War II-era uniforms, were stretched for several kilometers (miles) along Utah Beach ahead of commemorations marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings.\n\nUtah was one of the five landing beaches along the coast of Normandy where Allied troops landed on June 6, 2024. Utah and Omaha were taken -- at the cost of hundreds of lives -- by American forces, with the others stormed by troops from Britain and Canada, also killing many hundreds, plus others from France.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe long stretch of the Normandy coast is where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler's defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\n\nA fair-like atmosphere is fueled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell.\n\nSurviving veterans, who are around 100 years old now, are the VIPs of the day's events.\n\nNation & World At 100, this vet says the 'greatest generation' moniker fits 'because we saved the world' ASSOCIATED PRESS 2 min to read 'FREEDOM COSTS,' DENMARK'S PRIME MINISTER SAYS AS SHE MARKS D-DAY'S 80TH ANNIVERSARY\n\nCOPENHAGEN, Denmark -- Denmark's prime minister said that this year's observances of the D-Day landings, which come as Russia is at war against Ukraine, are a reminder that there is a price for defending freedom.\n\n\"From D-Day we have learned that freedom costs,\" Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said in a statement as she headed to Normandy for ceremonies marking the 80th anniversary of the Allied landings.\n\n\"Eighty years later, Europe once again finds itself at a fateful moment. Where freedom is once again being fought for on our own continent,\" she said, \"against an aggressive and brutal enemy who will dictate country borders with brute force and leave a trail of death and destruction.\"\n\nIMAGINING THE HORROR AND CELEBRATING FREEDOM\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- Because freedom is worth celebrating and passing on to children, too, Alexandra Hamon, 35, drank champagne and shared the sunrise with her boys, Karl and Neils, both 13, as the day dawned Thursday over the beaches where Allied soldiers landed on D-Day.\n\nThe family was among a crowd several thousands strong that stretched for kilometers along Utah beach -- one of the five beaches along the coast of Normandy where Allied troops landed. Utah and Omaha were taken -- at the cost of hundreds of lives -- by American forces, with the others stormed by troops from Britain and Canada, also killing many hundreds, plus others from France. The other code-named beaches are Juno, Sword and Gold.\n\nKarl sat perched on the hood of their 1943 Dodge truck, lovingly restored by her husband, Enogat, as the family from Saint Malo, a French coastal city that was badly damaged in major fighting about two months after D-Day, stared out across the English Channel.\n\nThe waters Thursday were still and peaceful -- unlike on that fateful day that helped change the course of WWII and precipitate Adolf Hitler's downfall 11 months later.\n\n\"It's indescribable, just imagining the chaos. Now it's peaceful, almost festive, we try to imagine but I think it's unimaginable,\" she said.\n\n\"You think of all those guys, everything they went through,\" she added of the fast-dwindling D-Day veterans. \"They say they aren't heroes. But they are, they are. Those guys really should never die. I imagine the boats, the guys arriving, the sounds. It must have been horrible, yes, horrible.\"\n\nKEEPING ALIVE THE MEMORY OF SOLDIERS 'WHO DIED FOR OUR FREEDOM'\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- As the rising sun took the night's chill off Utah Beach, Christophe Receveur, 57, from Thionville in eastern France, unfurled a Stars and Stripes he bought in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, six months ago specifically to honor the Americans who fell on D-Day.\n\n\"To keep alive the memory of the soldiers who died for our freedom,\" he said. \"To forget them is to let them die all over again.\"\n\nReceveur and his daughter, Julie, 28, carefully folded the flag into a tight triangle after their quiet, reflective homage on an empty stretch of the beach, busy with hundreds of people strung out along the sands.\n\nReceveur said the Ukraine war was on his mind, too, as he honored the fallen of WWII. His great grandfather fought in WWI, his grandfather was a prisoner of war in WWII, and his father was a veteran of France's war in former North African colony Algeria.\n\n\"I don't want our freedom, for our kids, our grandkids, to be hit by ... I don't want to say a madman,\" referring to Russian President Vladimir Putin. \"So a lot of respect for these people who died and for those who are still dying,\" he said of the WWII dead and those in Ukraine.\n\nHe said the D-Day sacrifices have to be remembered. \"Lots of emotion that all these troops came to liberate a country that they didn't know for an ideology -- democracy, freedom -- that is under severe strain now.\"\n\n'WE JUST HAVE TO REMEMBER THE SACRIFICES'\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- As the golden sun pierced low clouds over the seas that were thick with landing craft approaching Normandy on D-Day, Becky Kraubetz peered across the English Channel toward her native Britain, her eyes filled with tears as she thought about the scene 80 years ago.\n\n\"It's so historic and we just have to remember the sacrifices of everybody who gave us our freedom,\" said Kraubetz, whose grandfather served with the British Army during World War II and was captured in Malta.\n\n\"It gives you goosebumps, everything that happened here. Imagine just jumping into the water, freezing cold,\" said the 54-year-old who now lives in Florida, as the rays of the morning sun started to warm the hundreds of people who'd waited through the night's chill for dawn's break.\n\n\"The bravery, the courage, for people to face that is just unbelievable -- very, very humbled to be here.\"\n\nTHE SUN RISES OVER NORMANDY BEACHES AS THE WORLD REMEMBERS D-DAY\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- As the sun sets on the D-Day generation, it's rising again over Normandy beaches where soldiers fought and died exactly 80 years ago, kicking off intense anniversary commemorations Thursday against the backdrop of renewed war in Europe, in Ukraine.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, make this anniversary particularly meaningful, mixing poignant remembrances for D-Day sacrifices with an Allied show of solidarity for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, among the guests.\n\nBut host France hasn't invited World War II ally Russia, citing its \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks.\"\n\nHUNDREDS GATHER AT DAWN AT UTAH BEACH TO MARK D-DAY'S 80TH ANNIVERSARY\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- Hundreds of people, some in WWII-era uniforms, arrived before dawn to stretch out across the now peaceful sands of Utah Beach, one of the five Allied landing zones on D-Day where troops waded into cold seas through hails of fire exactly 80 years ago.\n\n\"It's our way of paying homage, and better understanding what really happened in the 1944 landings,\" said Dimitri Picot, a 33-year-old from the nearby Normandy town of Carentan who works as a rat and pest catcher.\n\nPicot said he often dives on a wrecked ship that was hit and exploded, its wreckage visible Thursday as night gave way to day. Growing up amid the June 6, 1944, landing zones, he said he has become accustomed to seeing walls still pockmarked by bullets, shrapnel and other reminders of that fateful day.\n\nBut on the 80th anniversary \"to think that they liberated us\" hammered home the emotion, he said.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. In total, 6,330 ships and 10,440 aircraft were involved alongside 153,110 troops.\n\nThe forces divided across five beaches and, in less than a week, they were able to secure them, meaning the beaches could then be used to deliver more equipment, vehicles, and troops to the Allies going forward.\n\nThe operation was originally set to take place the day before, on June 5, but bad weather caused the forces to push it back.\n\nMany refer to D-Day and the Normandy landings as the \"beginning of the end\" of the Second World War and the Nazi's hold over Europe.\n\nThe estimates of how many passed away on D-Day vary. But, according to John Long, the director of education at the National D-Day Memorial Foundation, between 5,000 and 12,000 soldiers from the Allied Forces are thought to have died on D-Day.\n\nAs for German casualties, the number is predicted to be between 4,000 and 9,000, with the Allies capturing some 200,000 German prisoners of war.\n\nThe 'D' in D-Day is merely a code word used by the military to designate an occasion; it has no symbolic meaning.\n\nEven before they knew the exact date of the invasion, the military began organising the specifics of the operation. They called it D-Day to help plan things like when the troop ships should depart England.The 'D' is commonly understood to stand for day, therefore D-Day is really called Day Day.\n\nAlthough the name D-Day has been applied to other military events, the Allied invasion of Normandy is now closely linked to it.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": {"uri": "8164548451", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "11:16:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T11:16:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T11:15:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.fox5atlanta.com/news/d-day-80-years-later-facts-about-one-wwiis-most-pivotal-battles", "title": "D-Day 80th anniversary: Some facts about one of the most pivotal battles in WWII", "body": "June 6, 2024, marks the 80th anniversary of one of the largest air, land and sea invasions in military history. The Battle of Normandy, often referred to as D-Day and codenamed \"Operation Overlord,\" has been described by historians as a major turning point for the Allied forces in World War II.\n\nThe nearly 160,000 Allied troops, made up of American, British and Canadian forces, landed on the beaches of Nazi-occupied France and were then able to push inland to Western Europe.\n\nThe bravery displayed by these troops has been depicted in many books and films, including \"Saving Private Ryan\" and the book-turned-HBO miniseries \"Band of Brothers.\"\n\nRELATED: Haunting art installation marks D-Day anniversary: See the pics\n\nWhat does \"D\" stand for in D-Day? It depends on who you ask.\n\nSome say it stands for designated day, decision day, doomsday or even death day, according to the U.S. military.\n\nOthers also said it merely stands for \"Day,\" as in Day-Day.\n\nThere have been other instances in history which utilized D-Day as a coded designation for the day of any important invasion or military operation, the U.S. military said.\n\nReferencing Stephen Ambrose's book, \"D-Day, June 6, 1944: The Climactic Battle of World War II,\" the U.S. Army's first use of D-Day was in 1918.\n\n\"For military planners (and later historians), the days before and after a D-Day were indicated using plus and minus signs: D-4 meant four days before a D-Day, while D+7 meant seven days after a D-Day,\" according to the U.S. Army website.\n\nAn unknown person allegedly wrote to General Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Allied supreme commander for Operation Overlord, and asked what the \"D\" meant.\n\nHis executive assistant at the time, Brigadier Gen. Robert Schultz answered:\n\n\"General Eisenhower asked me to respond to your letter. Be advised that any amphibious operation has a 'departed date'; therefore the shortened term 'D-Day' is used,\" the Army's website reads.\n\nRELATED: D-Day veterans return to Normandy for 80th anniversary, share memories and messages for future generations\n\nAdolf Hitler's army had invaded France and was aiming to take over all of Europe. The Allies knew that a successful invasion of mainland Europe was key to winning the war.\n\nIn January 1944, Eisenhower was appointed Allied supreme commander for Operation Overlord.\n\nMany locations were considered in the planning stages of the invasion. According to the National D-Day Memorial Foundation, Normandy was ultimately chosen with one reason being its many weak sections along the Atlantic Wall, a series of concrete fortifications that Hitler ordered to be built along the coast.\n\nIn the months leading up to D-Day, the Allies set up decoy operations to confuse the Germans, according to the foundation. The code name for this deception was Operation Fortitude, and they intended to trick the Germans into thinking the main invasion target was Norway or Pas de Calais in northern France, rather than Normandy.\n\nThe Allies even created a \"dummy army\" called the First U.S. Army Group commanded by Lt. General George Patton, according to military historian and author Flint Whitlock.\n\nEisenhower and the Allied leaders postponed the planned D-Day from the beginning of May to June 5, 1944.\n\nHowever, bad weather a few days before June 5 caused further delay, pushing D-Day to June 6, according to History.com. After Eisenhower's meteorologists forecasted a short window of suitable conditions, he gave the go-ahead for Operation Overlord.\n\n\"The weather was still not perfect the day of Operation Overlord, but it allowed the Allies to gain the footing they needed on the European mainland,\" an explanation reads on the National D-Day Memorial Foundation website.\n\nThe sea landings started at 6:30 a.m., just after dawn, targeting five code-named beaches: Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno, Sword. The operation also included actions inland, including overnight parachute landings on strategic German sites and U.S. Army Rangers scaling cliffs to take out German gun positions.\n\nAround 13,000 Allied aircraft, 5,000 ships and boats, and thousands of other vehicles were involved.\n\nBy the end of June, the Allies had seized the key port of Cherbourg, according to historians.\n\nApproximately 850,000 men had landed in Normandy, and the Allied forces were set to push farther across France.\n\nBy the end of August 1944, Paris was liberated and the Nazis had been removed from northwestern France. This led to the Allied troops later entering Germany, where Soviet troops were advancing in the east.\n\nThe invasion of Normandy began to \"turn the tide\" against Nazi Germany. A History Channel description called it a \"significant psychological blow,\" preventing Hitler from sending troops from France to build up his Eastern front against the Soviets.\n\nBy May 8, 1945, the Allies would formally accept Nazi Germany's unconditional surrender.\n\nA total of 4,414 Allied troops were killed on D-Day itself, including 2,501 Americans. More than 5,000 were wounded.\n\nIn the ensuing Battle of Normandy, 73,000 Allied forces were killed and 153,000 wounded. The battle -- and especially the Allied bombings of French villages and cities -- killed around 20,000 French civilians.\n\nThe exact German casualties aren't known, but historians estimate between 4,000 and 9,000 men were killed, wounded or missing during the D-Day invasion alone. About 22,000 German soldiers are among the many buried around Normandy.\n\nWhile it's difficult to say exactly how many veterans who participated in the landing at Normandy are alive today, the National WWII Museum estimates less than 1% of the 16.4 million American soldiers who served during WWII are still alive and living in the U.S. as of 2023.", "source": {"uri": "fox5atlanta.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX 5 Atlanta"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Overlord", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Operation Overlord"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normandy_landings", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Normandy landings"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Dwight D. Eisenhower"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_history", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Military history"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nazi_Germany", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Nazi Germany"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Army", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "United States Army"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "World War II"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "United States Armed Forces"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_military_administration_in_occupied_France_during_World_War_II", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "German military administration in occupied France during World War II"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_E._Ambrose", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Stephen E. {"uri": "8164616876", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "11:57:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T11:57:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T11:57:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/news/nation-world/d-day-80th-anniversary-world-war-ii-veterans-normandy-beaches/article_b79a5cfe-4368-5d3b-82f5-4b485126ab4a.html", "title": "D-Day's 80th anniversary brings World War II veterans back to the beaches of Normandy", "body": "World War II veterans are joining heads of state and others on the beaches of Normandy to commemorate the 80th anniversary of D-Day\n\nWorld War II veterans joined heads of state and others Thursday on the beaches of Normandy to commemorate the 80th anniversary of D-Day.\n\nThe Allied invasion, which began on June 6, 1944, led to the defeat of the Nazis and the end of the war. The assault began with Allied aircraft bombing German defenses in Normandy, followed by around 1,200 aircraft that carried airborne troops. As dawn broke, Allied forces started bombing German coastal defenses and shortly after that vessels began putting troops ashore on five codenamed beaches: Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword. By the end of the day, nearly 160,000 Allied troops had landed in Normandy, although there were thousands of casualties.\n\nFew witnesses to history's biggest amphibious invasion remain alive today. Here's the latest:\n\nPRINCE WILLIAM PRAISES CANADIAN TROOPS IN NORMANDY People are also reading... Death of cyclists in Napa leads to criminal and civil lawsuits, documentary UPDATE: Crystal Fire progress stopped 'We feel identified': Thousands flock to Napa for La Onda's Latin music showcase Napa city Planning Commissioner Bob Massaro dies American Canyon High School student arrested after gun found in car NFL: Former Vintage High lineman and Super Bowl champion Allen dies at age 52 Fire damages commercial building in St. Helena Your guide to Festival La Onda: What to watch for, and how to get around downtown Napa Festival La Onda takes a bow Sunday, concludes Napa debut Napa man convicted of child molestation denied parole Latin music, Latino fans gained the Napa spotlight at La Onda Napa Police seeks information about motorcyclist reported missing Napa grand jury criticizes county building permits, golf tournament's treatment BottleRock organizers tap into the Latino market with Festival La Onda 'The Real Housewives of Napa Valley' debuts Friday\n\nJUNO BEACH, France -- Prince William has praised the bravery and sacrifice of Canadian troops as he addressed a D-Day anniversary ceremony on Juno Beach.\n\nThe royal was joined by Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal and Canadian D-Day veterans.\n\nSome 14,000 Canadians were part of the 150,000 Allied troops who landed or parachuted into Normandy in 1944.\n\n\"Far from home they stormed these very sand dunes behind me, shoulder to shoulder with thousands of British troops,\" William said.\n\nAddressing veterans at the ceremony, the royal added: \"Thank you for our freedom, and thank you for your service.\"\n\nNation & World He saw the horrors of Dachau. Now, this WWII veteran warns against Holocaust denial ASSOCIATED PRESS PRESIDENT BIDEN MEETS WITH AMERICAN VETERANS\n\nCOLLEVILLE-SUR-MER, France -- U.S. President Joe Biden met with American veterans of D-Day as he marked the invasion's 80th anniversary.\n\nVeterans who could stand were helped out of wheelchairs to pose for photos with the president and first lady Jill Biden. One hugged Biden, another saluted. When Biden learned it was the birthday of one of the veterans, he led the audience in singing 'Happy Birthday.'\n\nThe first lady clutched the arm of another veteran, Robert Gibson, to help him stand next to Biden as they shook hands. \"Don't get old,\" the 100-year-old man joked to the 81-year-old president, who was a toddler when D-Day took place.\n\nSteve Spielberg and Tom Hanks, the Hollywood heavyweights behind movies and television shows about World War II, were nearby.\n\nKING CHARLES AND QUEEN CAMILLA LEAD D-DAY COMMEMORATIONS AT NEW MEMORIAL IN FRANCE\n\nVER-SUR-MER, France -- King Charles III and Queen Camilla led commemorations at the new British Normandy Memorial in Ver-sur-Mer.\n\nCamilla wiped away a tear as actor Martin Freeman read words by 99-year-old D-Day veteran Joe Mines, recalling that \"I was 19 when I landed, but I was still a boy. I don't care what people say, I wasn't a man, I was a boy. And I didn't have any idea of war and killing.\"\n\nPrime Minister Rishi Sunak and Labour Party leader Keir Starmer took a break from campaigning for Britain's July 4 election to travel to France for the ceremony.\n\nSunak paid tribute to veterans, saying their \"actions freed a continent and built a better world.\"\n\n\"You risked everything and we owe you everything,\" he said. \"We cannot possibly hope to repay that debt but we can and we must pledge never to forget.\"\n\nWelsh singer Tom Jones, 83, sang his song \"I Won't Crumble With You If You Fall,\" before the king addressed the audience in French and English.\n\nCharles said that while the number of living veterans was dwindling, \"our obligation to remember what they stood for and what they achieved for us all can never diminish.\"\n\nSpeaking in French, Charles paid tribute to the \"unimaginable number\" of French civilians killed in the battle for Normandy, and the bravery and sacrifice of the French Resistance.\n\nMAN HONORS A GRANDFATHER HE NEVER KNEW, AN OFFICER WHO SMUGGLED HIMSELF ON A LANDING CRAFT\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- Among the thousands who flocked to D-Day beach Utah was the grandson of an American colonel who smuggled himself aboard a landing craft so he could join his men in the first waves of the June 6, 1944, invasion.\n\nJohn Reistrup, 55, never met his grandfather, Eugene M. Caffey, who died in 1961. Coming back to Utah for the 80th anniversary was his way of carrying \"the torch for someone you never met that had such an impact on so many lives.\"\n\nA plaque at the beach that honors his grandfather says the colonel led the 19,500 men of the 1st Engineer Special Brigade tasked on that fateful day with the logistics of the landing on Utah, one of five invasion beaches.\n\nNot scheduled to land until 0900, Caffey, a 49-year-old father of nine, had smuggled himself, with no equipment except an empty rifle, aboard an 8th Infantry landing craft. En route he managed to load his rifle by taking up a collection of one bullet each from eight infantrymen. He arrived ashore very early in the assault, Reistrup said.\n\n\"No officers were allowed on the first waves of the landing but he said, 'Hell, no, I'm going with my guys.'\"\n\nA Nazi bunker captured on the beach then became his grandfather's office, he said. Caffey's portrait hangs there, inside, to this day.\n\nForging ahead into fire on D-Day \"has got to be the greatest courage you could ever have,\" said Reistrup, who has visited Normandy about 10 times since his first visit as a kid in 1974.\n\nNation & World Jewish veteran from London prepares to commemorate 80th anniversary of D-Day landings DANICA KIRKA Associated Press 4 min to read THOUSANDS OF PEOPLE DOT FRANCE'S UTAH BEACH FOR D-DAY COMMEMORATIONS\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- Thousands of people, including many people in World War II-era uniforms, were stretched for several kilometers (miles) along Utah Beach ahead of commemorations marking the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings.\n\nUtah was one of the five landing beaches along the coast of Normandy where Allied troops landed on June 6, 2024. Utah and Omaha were taken -- at the cost of hundreds of lives -- by American forces, with the others stormed by troops from Britain and Canada, also killing many hundreds, plus others from France.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe long stretch of the Normandy coast is where the largest-ever land, sea and air armada punctured Hitler's defenses in Western Europe and helped precipitate his downfall 11 months later.\n\nA fair-like atmosphere is fueled by World War II-era jeeps and trucks tearing down hedge-rowed lanes so deadly for Allied troops who fought dug-in German defenders, and of reenactors playing at war on sands where D-Day soldiers fell.\n\nSurviving veterans, who are around 100 years old now, are the VIPs of the day's events.\n\nNation & World At 100, this vet says the 'greatest generation' moniker fits 'because we saved the world' ASSOCIATED PRESS 2 min to read 'FREEDOM COSTS,' DENMARK'S PRIME MINISTER SAYS AS SHE MARKS D-DAY'S 80TH ANNIVERSARY\n\nCOPENHAGEN, Denmark -- Denmark's prime minister said that this year's observances of the D-Day landings, which come as Russia is at war against Ukraine, are a reminder that there is a price for defending freedom.\n\n\"From D-Day we have learned that freedom costs,\" Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said in a statement as she headed to Normandy for ceremonies marking the 80th anniversary of the Allied landings.\n\n\"Eighty years later, Europe once again finds itself at a fateful moment. Where freedom is once again being fought for on our own continent,\" she said, \"against an aggressive and brutal enemy who will dictate country borders with brute force and leave a trail of death and destruction.\"\n\nIMAGINING THE HORROR AND CELEBRATING FREEDOM\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- Because freedom is worth celebrating and passing on to children, too, Alexandra Hamon, 35, drank champagne and shared the sunrise with her boys, Karl and Neils, both 13, as the day dawned Thursday over the beaches where Allied soldiers landed on D-Day.\n\nThe family was among a crowd several thousands strong that stretched for kilometers along Utah beach -- one of the five beaches along the coast of Normandy where Allied troops landed. Utah and Omaha were taken -- at the cost of hundreds of lives -- by American forces, with the others stormed by troops from Britain and Canada, also killing many hundreds, plus others from France. The other code-named beaches are Juno, Sword and Gold.\n\nKarl sat perched on the hood of their 1943 Dodge truck, lovingly restored by her husband, Enogat, as the family from Saint Malo, a French coastal city that was badly damaged in major fighting about two months after D-Day, stared out across the English Channel.\n\nThe waters Thursday were still and peaceful -- unlike on that fateful day that helped change the course of WWII and precipitate Adolf Hitler's downfall 11 months later.\n\n\"It's indescribable, just imagining the chaos. Now it's peaceful, almost festive, we try to imagine but I think it's unimaginable,\" she said.\n\n\"You think of all those guys, everything they went through,\" she added of the fast-dwindling D-Day veterans. \"They say they aren't heroes. But they are, they are. Those guys really should never die. I imagine the boats, the guys arriving, the sounds. It must have been horrible, yes, horrible.\"\n\nKEEPING ALIVE THE MEMORY OF SOLDIERS 'WHO DIED FOR OUR FREEDOM'\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- As the rising sun took the night's chill off Utah Beach, Christophe Receveur, 57, from Thionville in eastern France, unfurled a Stars and Stripes he bought in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, six months ago specifically to honor the Americans who fell on D-Day.\n\n\"To keep alive the memory of the soldiers who died for our freedom,\" he said. \"To forget them is to let them die all over again.\"\n\nReceveur and his daughter, Julie, 28, carefully folded the flag into a tight triangle after their quiet, reflective homage on an empty stretch of the beach, busy with hundreds of people strung out along the sands.\n\nReceveur said the Ukraine war was on his mind, too, as he honored the fallen of WWII. His great grandfather fought in WWI, his grandfather was a prisoner of war in WWII, and his father was a veteran of France's war in former North African colony Algeria.\n\n\"I don't want our freedom, for our kids, our grandkids, to be hit by ... I don't want to say a madman,\" referring to Russian President Vladimir Putin. \"So a lot of respect for these people who died and for those who are still dying,\" he said of the WWII dead and those in Ukraine.\n\nHe said the D-Day sacrifices have to be remembered. \"Lots of emotion that all these troops came to liberate a country that they didn't know for an ideology -- democracy, freedom -- that is under severe strain now.\"\n\n'WE JUST HAVE TO REMEMBER THE SACRIFICES'\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- As the golden sun pierced low clouds over the seas that were thick with landing craft approaching Normandy on D-Day, Becky Kraubetz peered across the English Channel toward her native Britain, her eyes filled with tears as she thought about the scene 80 years ago.\n\n\"It's so historic and we just have to remember the sacrifices of everybody who gave us our freedom,\" said Kraubetz, whose grandfather served with the British Army during World War II and was captured in Malta.\n\n\"It gives you goosebumps, everything that happened here. Imagine just jumping into the water, freezing cold,\" said the 54-year-old who now lives in Florida, as the rays of the morning sun started to warm the hundreds of people who'd waited through the night's chill for dawn's break.\n\n\"The bravery, the courage, for people to face that is just unbelievable -- very, very humbled to be here.\"\n\nTHE SUN RISES OVER NORMANDY BEACHES AS THE WORLD REMEMBERS D-DAY\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- As the sun sets on the D-Day generation, it's rising again over Normandy beaches where soldiers fought and died exactly 80 years ago, kicking off intense anniversary commemorations Thursday against the backdrop of renewed war in Europe, in Ukraine.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, make this anniversary particularly meaningful, mixing poignant remembrances for D-Day sacrifices with an Allied show of solidarity for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, among the guests.\n\nBut host France hasn't invited World War II ally Russia, citing its \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks.\"\n\nHUNDREDS GATHER AT DAWN AT UTAH BEACH TO MARK D-DAY'S 80TH ANNIVERSARY\n\nUTAH BEACH, France -- Hundreds of people, some in WWII-era uniforms, arrived before dawn to stretch out across the now peaceful sands of Utah Beach, one of the five Allied landing zones on D-Day where troops waded into cold seas through hails of fire exactly 80 years ago.\n\n\"It's our way of paying homage, and better understanding what really happened in the 1944 landings,\" said Dimitri Picot, a 33-year-old from the nearby Normandy town of Carentan who works as a rat and pest catcher.\n\nPicot said he often dives on a wrecked ship that was hit and exploded, its wreckage visible Thursday as night gave way to day. Growing up amid the June 6, 1944, landing zones, he said he has become accustomed to seeing walls still pockmarked by bullets, shrapnel and other reminders of that fateful day.\n\nBut on the 80th anniversary \"to think that they liberated us\" hammered home the emotion, he said.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8164372723", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "09:32:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T09:32:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T09:31:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/europe/normandy-invasion-what-happened-on-d-day/articleshow/110762374.cms", "title": "Normandy invasion: What happened on D-Day? - Times of India", "body": "NEW DELHI: To honor the 80th anniversary of D-Day, Western leaders, veterans on Thursday commemorated the 1944 World War II landings in northern France, which played a crucial role in liberating Europe from Nazi occupation. This also comes amid the ongoing war in Europe, over two years after Russia's invasion of Ukraine.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron hosted US president Joe Biden, King Charles III of the UK, and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, representing the Allied powers whose troops made the ultimate sacrifice during the Normandy landings on June 6, 1944.This pivotal event, codenamed Operation Overlord, marked a turning point in World War II, leading to the eventual downfall of Nazi Germany.\n\nThe commemoration will see the participation of approximately 150 American veterans, 15 Canadian veterans, and over 40 British WWII veterans in Normandy.\n\nD-Day\n\nOriginally scheduled for June 5, 1944, D-Day was delayed by 24 hours due to storms, awaiting optimal conditions of a full moon, low tides, and good weather.\n\nD-Day was a generic code for the start of any significant operation, with the initial 'D' representing 'Day.' Before the Allied invasion in June 1944, this term was commonly used. However, post-Operation Overlord, 'D-Day' became synonymous with the Normandy invasion.\n\nD-Day showcased an unprecedented level of international military collaboration, with over 2 million troops positioned in the UK in preparation for the invasion, according to the Imperial War Museums (IWM).\n\nA plan that was executed after a year\n\nThe planning for D-Day began over a year earlier and included extensive military deception to mislead the Germans about the invasion's timing and location. This strategy, known as Operation Bodyguard, encompassed Operation Fortitude, which aimed to convince the Nazis that the main invasion would occur in Norway (Fortitude North) and Pas de Calais (Fortitude South), not Normandy.\n\nHuman cost of the operation\n\nThe human cost of D-Day was staggering. On that single day, 4,414 Allied troops were killed, including 2,501 Americans, with more than 5,000 wounded. German casualties ranged between 4,000 and 9,000. The subsequent Battle of Normandy, lasting 77 days, resulted in 73,000 Allied forces killed and 153,000 wounded, with around 20,000 French civilians killed due to Allied bombings.\n\nEnd of Hitler\n\nD-Day is often described as the \"beginning of the end\" of Hitler's regime. The successful landings enabled the Allies to establish a foothold in Western Europe, leading to the liberation of France and the eventual defeat of Nazi Germany. Less than a year after D-Day, on May 7, 1945, Nazi Germany surrendered unconditionally, marking the end of World War II in Europe.\n\nThis year's commemoration holds particular significance against the backdrop of the ongoing conflict in Europe due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine.\n\n( with input from agencies)\n\nAt TOI World Desk, our dedicated team of seasoned journalists and passionate writers tirelessly sifts through the vast tapestry of global events to bring you the latest news and diverse perspectives round the clock. With an unwavering commitment to accuracy, depth, and timeliness, we strive to keep you informed about the ever-evolving world, delivering a nuanced understanding of international affairs to our readers. The invasion, which remains the largest amphibious assault in history, involved forces from the United States and the United Kingdom, as well as many other Allied nations.\n\nThe operation was a critical turning point in World War II, leading to the successful gaining of a foothold in mainland Europe and the eventual defeat of Nazi Germany.\n\nThe anniversary will be recognized by leaders across the world, with several representatives from Allied countries convening at the Normandy American Cemetery, which holds the graves of nearly 9,400 U.S. soldiers and commemorates nearly 1,600 names on the Walls of the Missing. D-Day is also used to celebrate surviving soldiers who fought in the battle, with hundreds of veterans often in attendance.\n\nThe ceremony will be attended by President Joe Biden, French President Emmanuel Macron, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, and Britain's Prince William.\n\nThere will be a fireworks display on Normandy Beach and Biden will also be travelling to Cherbourg on June 7 to attend another ceremony commemorating the event.\n\nHow much do you know about the momentous events of that day? {"uri": "8164265486", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "08:25:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T08:25:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T08:24:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13500367/Joe-Jill-Biden-Normandy-D-Day-80th-anniversary-Ukraine.html", "title": "Joe and Jill Biden arrive in Normandy to mark D-Day's 80th anniversary", "body": "By Emily Goodin, Senior U.S. Political Reporter In Normandy and Rob Crilly, Senior U.S. Political Reporter In Normandy\n\nPresident Joe Biden and first lady Jill Biden arrived in Normandy on Thursday morning to mark the 80th anniversary of the storming of the beaches there.\n\nIn his remarks, Biden will compare the struggle of Europe to defeat the Nazis to the current battle in the Ukraine, where Russian President Vladimir Putin has stepped up his attacks.\n\n'Today, in 2024, 80 years later, we see dictators once again attempting to challenge the order, attempting to march in Europe,' said National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan.\n\nHe added that Biden will 'be drawing a throughline from World War II through the Cold War and the stand up of the greatest military alliance the world has ever known, the NATO alliance, to today, where we face once again war in Europe, where NATO has rallied to defend freedom and sovereignty in Europe.'\n\nBiden will speak at the American Cemetery in Colleville-sur-Mer, where there are 9,388 graves of American dead, most of them in the form of white Latin crosses.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and first lady Jill Biden arrive at the Caen-Carpiquet Airport in Carpiquet, France, enroute to ceremonies to mark the 80th anniversary of D-Day\n\nPlanes fly over the beaches at Arromanches in Normandy\n\nHe'll also meet with American veterans who fought in D-Day. French President Emmanuel Macron will join him at the event.\n\nThe 172.5 acre cemetery was established by the U.S. First Army on June 8, 1944 as the first American cemetery on European soil in World War II.\n\nA French and American flag decorated each grave site. The cemetery was quiet in the early morning hours before it was filled with the 10,000 people to mark the anniversary of the landing on Omaha Beach below.\n\nThursday is a sunny, beautiful day - a sharp contrast to the weather 80 years ago, when troops battled the wind and rain to reach the beaches.\n\nThe only sounds were the birds in the trees and the waves of the English Channel. A few rabbits ran on the outskirts of the cemetery proper. The area was French farmland before it was gifted to the United States for the burial of American dead.\n\nA Navy destroyer sat off-shore, a single reminder of the 6,939 vessels that stormed the beaches 80 years ago. B-52 bombers flew overhead.\n\nThe Normandy landings, code named Operation Neptune, was the largest sea, air and land invasion in history. It was the start of the downfall of Adolf Hitler and the defeat of Nazi Germany.\n\nThe assault began with Allied aircraft bombing German defenses in Normandy, followed by around 1,200 aircraft that carried airborne troops.\n\nAs the sun rose, ships began putting troops ashore on five codenamed beaches: Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword. By the end of the day, nearly 160,000 Allied troops had landed in Normandy. There were thousands of casualties.\n\nThis year's ceremony is thought to be one of the last major anniversaries that will see D-Day veterans attend. The men and women who fought in the conflict are now in their 90s or older. Less than 1% of of the 16.4 million Americans who served during World War II are alive today.\n\nU.S. military personnel arrive at the Normandy American Cemetery above Omaha Beach\n\nSun rises over Omaha Beach near Colleville-sur-Mer Normandy\n\nFrance's President Emmanuel Macron (center) and France's First Lady Brigitte Macron (second right) are welcomed by French officials as they arrive at Normandy\n\nThis photograph is believed to show E Company, 16th Regiment, 1st Infantry Division, participating in the first wave of assaults during D-Day in Normandy\n\nAlso on Thursday King Charles and British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak will part in a ceremony later in the day to honor them and the British troops who also landed on Sword beach, while Prince William will participate in a ceremony for the Canadian troops who landed on Juno beach that will also include Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.\n\nLater in the day, Biden will join international leaders in marking the solomn anniversary, which comes as the allies show solidarity to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, who will be among the guests.\n\nIt will take place on Omaha Beach, site of some of the heaviest, deadliest fighting between U.S. forces and the German occupiers in France.\n\nRussia was not invited even though the role of the Soviet Red Army played a critical role in the defeat of Hitler. A decade ago, President Vladimir Putin attended the 70th anniversary celebration.\n\nBiden will return to Normandy on Friday to deliver a second speech, this time at Pointe du Hoc, where Army Rangers scaled the cliffs as German gunfire rained down on them.\n\nHe will make what the White House is billing as a major speech, where he will warn about the threats to democracy and the rise of dictators.\n\n'It's going to be action packed and, I think, extremely moving,' Sullivan said, adding that it's an 'opportunity for him to say thank you directly to the veterans who saved democracy, saved the free world, and set the stage for the decades of peace and prosperity that followed.'", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [],
