{"uri": "2024-06-380797136", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "11:40:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T11:40:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T11:37:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/06/06/europe/prince-william-king-charles-d-day-anniversary-intl/index.html", "title": "King Charles travels to mark D-Day anniversary while Prince William takes greater role", "body": "King Charles III speaks during a commemorative event for the 80th anniversary of D-Day, held at the British Normandy Memorial in Ver-sur-Mer, Normandy, France, on June 6.\n\nEditor's Note: This is a version of CNN's Royal News, a weekly dispatch bringing you the inside track on Britain's royal family. Sign up here.\n\nBritain's King Charles III has embarked on his first overseas trip since being diagnosed with cancer, traveling across the English Channel for commemorations marking the 80th anniversary of the 1944 D-Day Landings in Normandy.\n\nNearly 160,000 Allied troops landed on five stretches of the German-occupied Normandy coastline on June 6, 1944. Operation Overlord - as D-Day was codenamed - remains, to this day, the largest amphibious invasion in history, and was a crucial turning point in defeating the Nazis in World War II.\n\nOmaha Beach was the deadliest of the landing sites as German forces were entrenched in fortified cliff positions above allowing them to fire on the first waves of US soldiers as they reached the shore.\n\nNearly 10,000 Allied troops were killed or wounded on D-Day. Exact figures of German casualties on the day are not known, however it has been estimated to be between 4,000 and 9,000 service personnel.\n\nOn Thursday morning, King Charles and Queen Camilla attended the UK Ministry of Defence and the Royal British Legion's commemorative event at the British Normandy Memorial at Ver-sur-Mer. Charles is patron of both the Royal British Legion and Normandy Memorial Trust.\n\nKing Charles and Queen Camilla were joined by French President Emmanuel Macron and his wife Brigitte Macron at the British Normandy Memorial.\n\nChris Jackson/Getty Images\n\nThe King urged allies to \"recall lessons that come to us again and again,\" while addressing D-Day veterans.\n\n\"How fortunate we were and the entire free world that a generation of men and women in the United Kingdom and other allied nations did not flinch when the moment came to face that test,\" Charles said, adding that his grandfather, King George VI, described the events of D-Day as \"the supreme test.\"\n\nCharles reflected on the qualities of the armed forces involved, saying they \"carried out their duty with a humbling sense of resolve and determination.\"\n\nHe also used the speech to reflect on the past through the lens of the present, saying: \"We recall the lesson that comes to us again and again across the decades. Three nations must stand together to oppose tyranny.\"\n\nAmerican troops storm the beaches of Normandy, France, on June 6, 1944.\n\nRobert F. Sargent/Getty Images\n\nThe British Army's 50th Infantry Division lands on beaches in Normandy. Allied troops landed on five stretches of the Normandy coastline that were code-named Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword.\n\nCourtesy Imperial War Museum\n\nUS servicemen in New York read news about the D-Day invasion. The operation was led by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who would later become president of the United States.\n\nEd Jackson/NY Daily News Archive/Getty Images\n\nCommandos with the British Royal Navy advance on the beach. Planning for D-Day began more than a year in advance, and the Allies carried out substantial military deception to confuse the Germans as to when and where the invasion would take place.\n\nCourtesy Imperial War Museum\n\nUS Coast Guard boats are seen off Omaha Beach on the morning of D-Day. Troops left the USS Samuel Chase early that day to head to Normandy. \"When the order 'Lower Away' came, everything was quiet,\" Sargent recalled. \"Just the squeaking of the davits and the whispered comments of the men were heard. The soldiers were silent.\"\n\nUniversal History Archive/Universal Images Group/Getty Images\n\nMedics start an IV as they assist a wounded soldier on shore. Heavy fire from German positions caused many casualties.\n\nCorbis/Getty Images\n\nA squadron of Lockheed P-38 Lightnings, under the command of US Air Force Lt. Col. Clarence Shoop, fly across the English countryside on their way to France on D-Day.\n\nFPG/Getty Images\n\nEisenhower, supreme commander of the Allied forces, gives the order of the day to paratroopers in England. \"Full victory -- nothing else\" was the command just before they boarded their planes to participate in the first wave.\n\nMPI/Getty Images\n\nReinforcements disembark from boats at Normandy.\n\nHulton Archive/Getty Images\n\nUS paratroopers fix their static lines before a jump over Normandy. The Allied invasion -- codenamed Operation Overlord -- was coordinated across air, land and sea.\n\nAP Photo/U.S. Army Signal Corps\n\nLanding craft and a fleet of protection vessels approach Omaha Beach. By midnight, the troops had secured their beachheads and moved further inland.\n\nCorbis/Getty Images\n\nBritish troops reach the shore in the early morning. According to the Royal British Legion, the phrase D-Day was used fairly often before the Normandy landings. After them, however, the two became synonymous, and now D-Day is commonly understood to refer to the beginning of Operation Overlord.\n\nImago/Piemags/Reuters\n\nBritish troops use radios during the move inland.\n\nImago/Piemags/Reuters\n\nFrench soldiers are transported on the Normandy beaches. Most troops on D-Day were American, British and Canadian, according to the Imperial War Museums, but troops also came from Australia, Belgium, the Czech Republic, France, Greece, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe) and Poland.\n\nAFP/Getty Images\n\nA B-26 from the US Air Force flies over one of the beaches during the invasion.\n\nJeffrey Markowitz/Sygma/Getty Images\n\nThese US soldiers reached Omaha Beach aboard a life raft.\n\nGalerie Bilderwelt/Getty Images\n\nBritish tanks are seen on an American landing barge crossing the English Channel.\n\nUS Coast Guard/Keystone/Hulton Archive/Getty Images\n\nUS troops huddle behind the protective front of their landing craft as it nears a beachhead in France. Smoke in the background is naval gunfire giving cover to troops on land. Germans rained mortars and artillery down on Allied troops, killing many before they could even get out of their boats. Fighting was especially fierce at Omaha Beach, where Nazi fighters nearly wiped out the first wave of invading forces and left the survivors struggling for cover.\n\nU.S. Army\n\nInjured American soldiers wait to be moved to a field hospital after storming Omaha Beach.\n\nTime Life Pictures/National Archives/Getty Images\n\nUS troops wait to disembark a landing craft on D-Day. The Allies went to elaborate lengths to maintain secrecy and mislead Adolf Hitler. They employed double agents and used decoy tanks and phony bases in England to hide actual troop movements.\n\nKeystone/Getty Images\n\nAmerican troops help their injured comrades after their landing craft was fired upon.\n\nFox Photos/Getty Images\n\nThe crew on the British frigate HMS Holmes keep watch as gliders pass overhead with reinforcements from the 6th Airborne Division.\n\nImago/Piemags/Reuters\n\nBodies of American soldiers lie on the ground in Normandy as graves are dug.\n\nFox Photos/Getty Images\n\nBritish troops escort German prisoners in Normandy.\n\nImago/Piemags/Reuters\n\nA makeshift monument pays tribute to a fallen American soldier at Normandy.\n\nFPG/Hulton Archive/Getty Images\n\nThe D-Day landings, in pictures\n\nPrev Next\n\nCharles also spoke in French, thanking the people of France for their \"warmth\" and \"generosity\" towards D-Day veterans, which he said is the \"most moving and memorable part of these anniversaries.\"\n\nWhile the King traveled to France for commemorations, he is not expected to join world leaders - including Macron and his US counterpart Joe Biden - later Thursday as they gather at Omaha Beach to honor troops for their bravery and sacrifice eight decades ago. Instead, Prince William will represent Britain's royal family at the international ceremony at Omaha Beach.\n\nThe optics of seeing the Prince of Wales instead of his father will not be lost on those within the royal household, as well as royal-watchers. Nonetheless, CNN understands that it wasn't a deliberate orchestration.\n\nSeeing the future monarch in the company of other heads of state is a powerful visual and speaks to the longer transition which will prepare the public for King William V's reign.\n\nKing Charles also only recently returned to public engagements after getting the green light from his doctors who were \"encouraged\" by his progress.\n\nHe is continuing to receive treatment and each engagement the 75-year-old sovereign carries out is being reviewed and adapted where necessary by his medical team to ensure his continued recovery.\n\nThat simple reason of following medical advice appears to be behind the King's absence at the international commemoration on Thursday afternoon. A royal source told CNN that it was considered a step too far at this stage but that the monarch was delighted the Prince of Wales was representing the nation.\n\nWilliam, 42, has been an ever-present fixture as the royal family marked the D-Day anniversary in recent days. Earlier Thursday, the heir to the British throne paid tribute at the Canadian commemorative ceremony at the Juno Beach Centre in Courseulles-Sur-Mer, where he joined veterans as well as current serving personnel before making a speech and laying a wreath.\n\nPrince William meets Richard Rohmer, 100, one of the most decorated Canadian veterans, accompanied by the Prime Minister of France Gabriel Attal and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau during the Canadian government ceremony at Juno Beach on Thursday.\n\nJordan Pettitt/Getty Images\n\nA day earlier, William had joined Charles and Camilla at the UK's national commemorative event in Portsmouth. The city on England's south coast was one of the places Allied troops sailed from before the Normandy landings.\n\nWilliam paid tribute to veterans who \"came from across our nation and from all walks of life to join in the fight against tyranny. Many of those that took up arms had never seen combat before, some were still only in their teens.\"\n\nMeanwhile, in his own moving speech, King Charles told crowds that \"the stories of courage, resilience and solidarity\" must not be forgotten and that they are a reminder \"of what we owe to that great wartime generation.\"\n\nCharles added: \"It is our duty to ensure that we, and future generations, do not forget their service and their sacrifice.\"\n\nCNN's Jessie Gretener contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "cnn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNN"}, "authors": {"uri": "8164702786", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:51:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:51:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:48:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/biden-d-day-anniversary-fallen-123927703.html", "title": "Biden on D-Day anniversary: These fallen saved the world. 'Let us be worthy of their sacrifice'", "body": "COLLEVILLE-SUR-MER, France - They came by the thousands, back to the hilltop overlooking the sea.\n\nOn a sunny afternoon in late spring, World War II veterans in the winter of life, many of them in wheelchairs or supported by canes, returned alongside President Joe Biden, French President Emmanuel Macron and other dignitaries to remember a bloody day that changed the world.\n\nFrom the hallowed ground where many of their fallen comrades rest beneath French soil, they honored the dead and commemorated the events of June 6, 1944, which the world now knows as D-Day.\n\n\"If you want to know the price of freedom, come here to Normandy,\" said Biden, who, at 81, was just a toddler on the day of the D-Day landings.\n\nEighty years ago, some 160,000 troops from the United States, Canada, Great Britain and other allies descended upon these shores in Normandy by air, land and seat to liberate Nazi-occupied France.\n\nThe fighting was brutal and the casualties enormous - more than 4,400 Allied troops were killed - but the unprecedented show of unified military power would mark the beginning of the end of Nazi Germany's grip on Europe.\n\n\"It is difficult to underestimate or undersell the significance of D-Day and what happened on D-Day,\" said Charles Djou, secretary of the American Battle Monuments Commission, which manages and operates 24 American military cemeteries abroad. \"Everything in this world turned on that day. And the fact that we succeeded on that day has made America and the world, the West, what it is.\"\n\nThe heroes of D-Day \"kept freedom alive,\" Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said.\n\n\"You saved the world. We must only defend it,\" he said. \"Gentlemen, we salute you.\"\n\nSome of the veterans who came back to France on Thursday for ceremonies marking the 80 anniversary of D-Day had been among the first to arrive and fight. A crowd estimated at 10,000 to 12,000 attended the ceremony at the Normandy American Cemetery, including 17 four-star officers, more than 150 members of Congress and dozens of members of the French Parliament. Other ceremonies also were scheduled and were expected to draw 25 heads of state.\n\nAn ocean breeze floated across the American cemetery, fluttering the small American and French flags on each of the graves of nearly 9,400 Americans killed in the war. Sunlight lit the white marble crosses and stars of David that mark each burial site.\n\nJust off the shore, Navy battleships stood guard in the English Channel. Men in military fatigues looked out over the sea from the grassy hillside where allied soldiers advanced and encountered German machine-gun fire.\n\nOne by one, Biden and first lady Jill Biden met with veterans ahead of the ceremony from a glass-backed gazebo overlooking Omaha Beach, where many of the soldiers came ashore eight decades ago. Biden saluted, took photos with each and handed them a coin that he said had been especially minted for the event.\n\nIn his remarks, Biden drew parallels between the Allied troops who fought to free Europe during World War II and the alliance of nations that has banded together to defend Ukraine in its war with Russia.\n\nThose who fought in World War II \"did their duty,\" he said, but \"that does not absolve us of what we have to do.\"\n\n\"In memory of those who fought here, died here, literally saved the world here, let us be worthy of their sacrifice,\" Biden said. \"Let us be the generation that, when history is written about our time ... it will be said, when the moment came, we met the moment.\"\n\nMore: As Joe Biden marks D-Day anniversary, he faces a world again embroiled in conflict\n\nBeyond the powerful symbolism of Thursday's events was the sobering reality that for many of the veterans, the ceremony would be their last. The youngest World War II veterans are in their mid-90s, and many of them are well over 100.\n\nOf the 16.4 million Americans who served in the war, just 119,000 - less than 1% of them - are still alive, according to the National World War II Museum in New Orleans. They are dying at a rate of 131 per day.\n\nSome veterans who attended the ceremony said they did so out of a sense of obligation. Others said they came because they again wanted to see where so many of their friends and brothers had died to preserve freedom.\n\n\"I'm not a very emotional guy,\" said John Gleeson, an Army Air Corps veteran from Honolulu, Hawaii, but \"I do things that I feel needs to be done.\"\n\nGleeson, who is 100, said fighting to defending American culture during the war had meant a lot to him. \"It still does,\" he said, which is one of the reasons he flew more than 7,000 miles to the events.\n\nMore: On D-Day, they changed the world. 80 years later, an incredible journey takes them back.\n\nLes Schrenk, a 100-year-old veteran from Bloomington, Minnesota, said D-Day is \"a part of my story. It's a story I've lived all these years.\"\n\nSchrenk, who joined the Amy Air Corps the day after the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor, was a gunner aboard a B-17 that was hit by German anticraft fire over the English Channel. The crippled plane made it to land over Denmark, but Schrenk and other crew members were forced to parachute to safety. Waiting for them on the ground were German soldiers, who captured him and took him as a prisoner of war.\n\nFor years, Schrenk wondered about the German pilot whose gunfire had shot and disabled his B-17. Who was he? Why didn't he finish off the Americans while they were still over water?\n\nWith the help of a friend, Schrenk tracked down the pilot, Hans Hermann Muller, in 2012. The two wartime enemies met in Heidelberg and formed the unlikeliest of friendship. Schrenk finally got an answer to the question that had haunted him for years.\n\n\"He said, 'Yes, I could have shot you down, but why should I,'\" Schrenk recalled\n\nIf he had shot the plane down over the water, Muller explained, the Americans would have had no chance of survival. Every one of them would have died.\n\n\"He spared my life,\" Schrenk said.\n\nMichael Collins covers the White House. Follow him on X, formerly Twitter, @mcollinsNEWS.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8164241014", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "08:11:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T08:11:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T08:09:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/minutes-silence-d-day-80th-113236252.html", "title": "Is there a minute's silence for D-Day 80th anniversary?", "body": "Today (June 6) marks the 80th anniversary of D-Day, when thousands of men died on the beaches of Normandy, France.\n\nOfficials have begun commemorations to honour the fallen, to pay tribute to the 156,000 Allied soldiers in World War Two who fought on the beaches of Normandy, to topple Adolf Hitler from power on June 6, 1944.\n\nBut can we, as a nation, honour the bravery of the fallen on June 6?\n\nHere is what you need to know.\n\nD-Day, also known as the Normandy Landings and 'the Longest Day', was the biggest seaborne invasion in military history. Troops from Great Britain, the Commonwealth, France, and the USA landed on the beaches of Normandy at several points along the coast to take the Germans by surprise.\n\nTheir mission was to free France from German occupation and the Allied victory that day signalled the beginning of the end of World War 2 and was a pivotal turning point in the conflict.\n\nFor most military commemorations, countries will remember those that have fallen with a minute's silence and D-Day is no different, with the tradition observed in the UK, France, US and the Commonwealth.\n\nArmistice Day silences take place on the hour and day the World War One Armistice was signed, at 11am on November 11.\n\nBut D-Day does not focus on one hour alone, and also does not mark the end of World War Two, which didn't conclude until months after the 1944 operation.\n\nThere are a number of services in place over the UK and Europe, where a silence will follow appearances from political and religious leaders.\n\nThe biggest commemoration of the day normally takes place at the American cemetery in Colleville-Sur-Mer, Normandy. {"uri": "8164860298", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:25:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:25:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:24:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://news.clearancejobs.com/2024/06/06/honoring-the-greatest-generation-on-the-80th-anniversary-of-d-day/", "title": "Honoring the Greatest Generation on the 80th Anniversary of D-Day", "body": "This year marks the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings in Normandy, France, which led to the Allied liberation of France and Western Europe, and more importantly the defeat of Nazi Germany. While it is certainly a time to celebrate the exploits of the Greatest Generation, given the passage of time, it will almost certainly be the last significant anniversary to see those who took were there still around to take part.\n\nAs CNN reported, Jack Foy - who is also a surviving of the Battle of the Bulge - joins the remaining veterans who made a pilgrimage back to Normandy this year. At 99 years old, Foy was described as \"the youngster among his group of friends.\"\n\nMajor commemorations have been held every five years, and organizers along with French government officials have acknowledged that 2024 will likely be the last to involve living veterans.\n\n\"We are perfectly aware that for these centenarians, this is maybe the last chance to return to the beaches where they landed, where they fought and where their brothers-in-arms fell,\" Gen. Michel Delion, the CEO of the French government agency in charge of the French commemoration efforts, Mission Liberation, told CNN.\n\nAround one-third of the adult male population served in the military during the Second World War, but according to the U.S. Department of Veteran Affairs, less than one percent is still alive.\n\nGetting the Vets to France\n\nAs young men, many barely out of high school, those who would storm the beaches or parachute into France on June 6, 1944, first took a boat ride to England, where they engaged in months of training. This week, the trip was a bit more comfortable for more than five dozen World War II veterans.\n\nSixty-six of them, each accompanied by a family member or companion, gathered in Texas after being chosen to make an \"honor flight\" aboard a chartered 747 provided by American Airlines. At Dallas Forth Worth International Airport they were joined by six Medal of Honor winners from wars in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Vietnam as well as by two \"Rosie the Riveters\" - the women who contributed to the war effort in factories and shipyards.\n\nIn total, 280 individuals were in the entourage back to Normandy.\n\nThe average age of the 66 World War II veterans was reported to be just shy of 101, with the oldest being 107 while the youngest was 95. Those men and women arriving on the honor flight will join hundreds of others who have headed back to Normandy to mark the milestone anniversary.\n\nMass Parachute Event and a Motorcycle Parade\n\nEach spring, Normandy transforms from a relatively quiet coastal region on the English Channel in Northern France into the literal ground zero for the largest festival marking the liberation of Europe during the Second World. The region's cities and villages host parades and other celebrations, while the cemeteries hold more somber gatherings that honor those who gave their lives in the invasion and in the weeks that followed. The celebrations kicked off on Saturday, June 1, with more than 20 huge firework displays that lit up the sky simultaneously over the five landing beaches.\n\nDozens of World War II-themed events have been underway since, and that included small historic reenactments, memorials, and even a mass parachute drop. On Sunday, dozens dropped from three World War II C-47 transport aircraft - the same planes that delivered members of the British and U.S. Airborne divisions to Normandy 80 years ago.\n\nTwo of the aircraft - christened \"That's All, Brother\" and \"Placid Lassie,\" - were actual \"D-Day veterans.\" Those two planes were among the thousands of C-47s and other aircraft that took to the skies on June 6, 1944. The C-47s took off from Duxford, England, and made the same roughly 90-minute flight to Carentan, France.\n\nThis time it was a bit different, however.\n\nFor one the flight took place during the day instead of at night, and more importantly, there was no anti-aircraft fire that greeted the aircraft. Sunday's jumpers included an international civilian team of parachutists, many former soldiers. Among them was one woman, 61-year-old Dawna Bennett.\n\nOn the ground on Tuesday, approximately 150 U.S. Army vintage Harley Davidson motorcycles took part in a road parade not far from the D-Day beaches. Many of the participants donned World War II-style uniforms, helmets, and other equipment.\n\nWhile June 6, 2024, featured a gathering of Western leaders, including U.S. President Joe Biden, French President Emmanuel Macron, and the UK's King Charles, the events at Normandy began in March and will continue through October.\n\n\"Each anniversary year is the occasion to pay tribute to the fallen and to the veterans who will come to attend the commemorative events and celebrations organized in Normandy,\" the Normandy Tourism website noted. \"Lest we forget.\"\n\nTrue words indeed.", "source": {"uri": "8164901046", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:51:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:51:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:51:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/podcasts/spotlight-on-france/20240606-podcast-d-day-and-its-aftermath-seen-through-french-and-american-eyes-normandy-wwii", "title": "Spotlight on France - Podcast: D-Day and its aftermath seen through French and American eyes", "body": "The United States played a key role in the Allied effort to liberate Western Europe from the Nazis, but not everyone sees it in the same light. As France marks the 80th anniversary of D-Day, an American veteran reflects on the differing ways the US and France remember the war. Meanwhile, historians recall the large number of civilians killed during the Allied invasion and explain why US soldiers were not always welcomed as heroes.\n\nAs French President Emmanuel Macron welcomes world leaders, the real stars of the commemorations are the surviving veterans themselves - the men who landed on the Normandy beaches on 6 June 1944 and started liberating France from Nazi occupation. The youngest of the remaining D-Day veterans are now in their late 90s. Alan Shapiro, 99, was too young to take part in the landings, but joined the European Allied forces in the autumn of 1944 and flew transport carriers in the US air corps. He's struck by the love and recognition he's received in France, where war was a lived experience rather than a distant newsreel. He came to France through the association Retour des veterans en Normandie (Veterans Back to Normandy), based in the village of Cr\u00e9ances. Its founder, Valerie Gautier, talks about the lasting need to show gratitude for D-Day and WWII veterans. (Listen @4'20)\n\nThe story of D-Day and its aftermath is told differently depending on which side of the Atlantic you're on. American historian Mary Louise Roberts discusses how France has been erased from the US perspective on the landings. Meanwhile French historian Emmanuel Thi\u00e9bot, who directs a museum in Normandy dedicated to civilians during WWII, explains why Allied soldiers didn't always get a hero's welcome in towns that had been bombed in preparation for the invasion. And local survivor Henri, whose fianc\u00e9e and uncle were killed by Allied bombs, recalls the mixed feelings he had about the troops sent to liberate France. {"uri": "8164894623", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:47:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:47:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:47:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://usanews.net/breaking/25-amazing-rarely-seen-photographs-of-d-day.html", "title": "25 Amazing, Rarely-Seen Photographs of D-Day - USA News", "body": "On June 6, 1944, the world witnessed one of the most significant events in history - the Allied invasion of Normandy, also known as D-Day. This massive operation involved 12,000 aircraft, 7,000 ships, 13,000 paratroopers, and 150,000 troops from various countries, making it the largest amphibious invasion to date. The success of D-Day paved the way for the liberation of France and marked a turning point in World War II.\n\nAs we commemorate the 80th anniversary of D-Day, it is essential to remember the sacrifices made by the Allied troops. Over 4,000 soldiers lost their lives on the day of the invasion, with thousands more perishing in the ensuing battles. To honor their bravery and the historic significance of D-Day, we have curated 25 incredible and rarely-seen photographs from that fateful day.\n\n**British Troops Prepare for the Historic Invasion**\n\nIn the late hours of June 5, 1944, four 'stick' commanders from the 22nd Independent Parachute Company of the British 6th Airborne Division synchronized their watches before the daring parachute drop into Normandy. These officers, including Lieutenants Bobby de la Tour and Don Wells, were among the first Allied troops to set foot in France, marking the beginning of the liberation efforts.\n\n**American Soldiers Embark on a Mission**\n\nAmerican assault troops, led by Major Edward J. Waters, received a benediction from a Catholic Army Chaplain before hitting the beaches of France. Their determination and resolve were evident as they knelt on the British pier, ready to face the enemy and secure a foothold in Hitler's fortress.\n\n**Canadian Troops Land on Normandy Shores**\n\nCourageous Canadian soldiers, part of the Allied forces, landed on Courseulles beach in Normandy, prepared to fight for the freedom of Europe. Their unwavering commitment to the mission was reflected in their readiness to engage the enemy as soon as they touched the shore.\n\n**Remembering the Fallen**\n\nAs we reflect on the events of D-Day, it is crucial to pay tribute to the brave soldiers who made the ultimate sacrifice for freedom. Wooden crosses, soldiers' helmets, and flowers mark the graves of those who perished in battle, serving as a poignant reminder of the cost of war.\n\nAs we commemorate the 80th anniversary of D-Day, let us honor the memory of those who fought and died for a better future. {"uri": "2024-06-380569100", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "08:30:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T08:30:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T07:01:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.aol.com/d-day-80th-anniversary-see-070105664.html", "title": "D-Day 80th anniversary: See historical photos from 1944 invasion of Normandy beaches", "body": "D-Day 80th anniversary: See historical photos from 1944 invasion of Normandy beaches\n\nGabe Hauari, USA TODAY\n\nJune 6, 2024 at 9:01 AM\n\nOn June 6, 1944, the Allied invasion of Normandy, France became the largest amphibious military assault the world has ever seen. The success of the operation, called Operation Overlord and most commonly known as D-Day, is largely credited as being the beginning of the end of World War II.\n\nAccording to the Library of Congress, more than 150,000 Allied troops landed on the beaches of Normandy and the operation \"put the Allies on a decisive path toward victory.\" An estimated 11,590 aircraft and 6,938 ships and landing craft were part of the assault.\n\nThe Library of Congress says that starting with D-Day, the Allies \"pushed back against Axis forces until Germany was forced to surrender less than a year later.\"\n\nThe invasion resulted in over 6,000 American casualties and German casualties are estimated at between 4,000 to 9,000.\n\nAs we observe the 80th anniversary of D-Day, here's a look at some historic photos from the invasion.\n\nHere's how D-Day unfolded: 80 years ago, on the beaches of Normandy, WWII shifted course\n\nD-Day's effect on 2024 election: How D-Day's roots will play a crucial role in Trump-Biden battle in 2024 election\n\nHistoric photos from D-Day\n\nGabe Hauari is a national trending news reporter at USA TODAY. {"uri": "8164325127", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "09:05:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T09:05:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T09:03:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.berkshireeagle.com/opinion/columnists/william-lambers-80-years-on-d-day-inspires-courage-for-peace/article_404730fa-21e0-11ef-b475-47efd9ba4b4a.html", "title": "80 years on, D-Day inspires courage for peace", "body": "In the movie \"The Longest Day,\" there is a scene where German soldiers on the coast of France suddenly see an armada of U.S. and allied ships appear on the horizon. That scene depicted the start of the D-Day invasion of June 6, 1944, during World War II. D-Day began the liberation of Europe from Nazi German occupation.\n\nIt was a massive land, sea and air operation. Soldiers from the United States and the Allies bravely stormed the beaches of Normandy, France, 80 years ago on D-Day. They faced heavy fire from the German forces. Thousands of U.S. and Allied soldiers were killed or wounded. They sacrificed themselves in the battle to defeat Nazi Germany and save the world from tyranny. D-Day led to the end of World War II. Four years later, if you looked out into the waters off France you would still see armadas of ships from the United States. But these ships carried food and other aid needed to rebuild the country.\n\n\"American ships are still coming to France and will continue to come for a long time. But now these vessels do not bear engines of death and destruction. They bear materials for the reconstruction so necessary to bring peace and prosperity back to Europe\" said U.S. Ambassador Jefferson Caffery at a D-Day event in France in 1948.\n\nFor the D-Day invasion to succeed, it required the dedication and bravery of U.S. and Allied soldiers. The peace efforts that followed the war likewise needed the same spirit. For saving France and Europe from the enemies of hunger and poverty was also part of the liberation -- because war always creates hunger and poverty.\n\nIn fact, the forces to fight hunger and poverty embarked on D-Day via civil affairs units. These allied troops were to provide humanitarian aid in the liberated areas of France and beyond. This involved identifying sources of food and other supplies, and getting them where they needed to be. Shortages had to be anticipated. One report read \"it soon became clear that in the rural areas as well as in Bayeux the main difficulty was going to be shortage of wheat and flour which would make itself felt in three weeks' time.\"\n\nOne civil affairs unit set up a feeding center for refugees at a school in Amblie, France. A medical treatment facility was also established to treat refugees. A child was born in one of the camps set up by civil affairs.\n\nThe fight against hunger and poverty went on quietly behind the scenes of the U.S. and Allied invasion. And it continued for many years through the Marshall Plan, which rebuilt Europe after World War II.\n\nAs we reflect on the 80th anniversary of D-Day, let's also remember the ultimate goal of the invasion: to build a world at peace. Many lost their lives on D-Day trying to save the world. As we honor the courage of the soldiers who gave so much on D-Day, let's also continue their quest for world peace. Let's show the same courage to build peace that the soldiers of D-Day had in the invasion and winning World War II. Just as D-Day forces sought to end a war and provide humanitarian aid to the needy, we should seek to end conflicts and hunger around the globe.\n\nReflecting on D-Day, Gen. Omar Bradley in 1947 wrote in The New York Times: \"Today it seems strange that in an operation as risky as a cross-channel invasion, we could keep that confidence in success -- while in an undertaking as full of promise as peace should be, we surrender so easily to our doubts and our fears.\"\n\nD-Day showed that America, with its allies, can overcome any challenge. Courage, unity, dedication and humanitarianism made D-Day and the liberation of Europe a reality. Let's channel that same spirit and bravely pursue the world of peace that soldiers on D-Day sacrificed everything to build.", "source": {"uri": "berkshireeagle.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Berkshire Eagle"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normandy_landings", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Normandy landings"}}, {"uri": In all, 4,414 Allied troops were killed on the first day of the invasion, including 381 Canadians.\n\nJune 6th marked just the beginning of the bloody 77-day Battle of Normandy and the start of the Allied liberation of France.\n\nIn the end, the toll was enormous: 73,000 Allied forces were killed and 153,000 wounded. Around 20,000 French civilians were also killed, many as a result of Allied bombings of French villages and cities.\n\nHistorians estimate about 22,000 German soldiers are among those buried around Normandy, and between 4,000 and 9,000 of them were killed, wounded or went missing during the D-Day invasion alone.\n\nThe region's cemeteries are also the final resting place for more than 5,000 {"uri": "2024-06-380843060", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:19:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:19:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:07:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://eu.elpasotimes.com/story/life/holiday/2024/06/06/d-day-june-6-1944-see-historical-photos-of-normandy-invasion/73995330007/", "title": "D-Day Anniversary: Normandy invasion remembered for World War II impact", "body": "Biden is in France to commemorate the 80th anniversary of D-Day, when 150,000 allied troops stormed the beaches of Normandy to liberate Europe.\n\nOn June 6, 1944, the Allied invasion of Normandy, France, became the largest amphibious military assault the world had ever seen.\n\nThe success of the operation, called Operation Overlord and most commonly known as D-Day, is largely credited as being the beginning of the end of World War II.\n\nMore than 150,000 Allied troops landed on the beaches of Normandy and the operation \"put the Allies on a decisive path toward victory.\" An estimated 11,590 aircraft and 6,938 ships and landing craft were part of the assault, according to the Library of Congress.\n\nWhy is it called D Day? What does D day stand for?\n\nMany experts have varying opinions, including that the D simply stood for \"day,\" a code used for any important military operation. Others have said it's just alliteration, like \"H-Hour,\" when a military assault begins, according to the U.S. Department of Defense.\n\nWhile the true meaning remains up for debate, we'll go with what U.S. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said about it through his executive assistant, Brig. Gen. {"uri": "2024-06-380824871", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:05:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:05:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/dozens-wwii-vets-flown-france-120000729.html", "title": "Dozens of WWII Vets Flown to France to Mark D-Day's 80th Anniversary: 'Our Duty and Honor'", "body": "\"For me, it's been a lifetime journey of honoring World War II veterans every year,\" one organizer of the trip tells PEOPLE\n\nThursday marks the 80th anniversary of D-Day -- the moment that turned the tide of World War II -- and to commemorate, a group of American veterans is gathering in France for what organizers say is an especially poignant milestone.\n\nThrough the combined efforts of Delta Airlines, Best Defense Foundation and Michelin North America, approximately four dozen veterans were flown on Sunday, June 2, to Deauville, Normandy, from Atlanta to mark the anniversary of the historic Allied invasion.\n\nIt marks the third consecutive time Delta has brought American veterans to France for D-Day celebrations. At the same time, their numbers have dwindled with age and illness.\n\n\"As time passes quickly for our WWII generation, it is our duty and honor to provide this opportunity of closure and camaraderie for those who gave so much,\" Donnie Edwards, president of the non-profit Best Defense Foundation, said in a statement.\n\n\"The idea came that maybe flying directly to Normandy would be just incredible,\" Virginie Durr, Delta's enterprise sales manager, told PEOPLE ahead of the veterans' visit. \"To be honest, I thought it was such a crazy idea -- it would never happen. But it came to the ears of people like our CEO [Ted Bastian] and he said, yeah, that's the right thing to do.\"\n\n\"During COVID, we were losing World War II veterans quite rapidly,\" Durr adds. \"Basically the people of Delta rallied around what it's about: serving our veterans.\"\n\nRelated: Photographer Captures Moving Portraits of Last WWII Veterans and Learns Their Survival Stories\n\nThe successful invasion of Normandy on June 6, 1944, marked a decisive shift in the war. On that day, over 4,400 Allied troops died, with 2,500 of them Americans.\n\nOn Tuesday, June 4, the returning veterans paid tribute to their fallen comrades at Normandy American Cemetery, according to Delta. They also visited the Overlord Museum for a tank demonstration and attended a gala dinner hosted by Normandy's president, Herv\u00e9 Morin.\n\nFor Durr, the program is personal as she is originally from Normandy.\n\n\"My grandparents were liberated by people like [the American veterans],\" she says. \"So for me, it's been a lifetime journey of honoring World War II veterans every year. Now I'm in America and I grew up with this passion and love for Americans who came to liberate us.\"\n\nRelated: WWII Vet Who Escaped Nazis Finally Gets Purple Heart, Prisoner of War Medal Nearly 80 Years Later\n\nHarold Terens, 100, now lives in Florida and was one of the veterans who was recently flown to France courtesy of Delta.\n\nHe still remembers the Allied invasion of Normandy. As a member of the Army Air Forces, he communicated with the pilots who went into battle that day. Terens himself would later head to Normandy 12 days later after the landings.\n\nNever miss a story -- sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.\n\n\"I was painting white stripes on the planes that remained,\" Terens tells PEOPLE. \"We had three separate missions back and forth, and we lost half of our planes and half of our pilots that day. It was one of the saddest days in my first 20 years of life.\"\n\n\"Most of the pilots were my friends,\" he says. \"The average age was 26. We were all kids.\"\n\n\"Normandy was just a horror to look at,\" he goes on to add. \"I still have nightmares about the war.\"\n\nRelated: Veterans Return to Normandy on 78th Anniversary of D-Day and Remember Life-Changing Moments of WWII\n\nDuring their visit to France for this year's D-Day commemoration, the veterans will be honored with parades and ceremonies before they return to the U.S. on June 12.\n\n\"The 80th Anniversary of the D-Day Landings in Normandy will be a very special opportunity to honor WWII Veterans through various events, and also to pass the torch of remembrance to the next generation,\" Morin, Normandy's president, said in a statement.\n\nFor Durr, it's about respect for those who fought for freedom in the war. She considers it gratifying to be involved in Delta's program for what could be some of these veterans' last D-Day commemoration in France.\n\n\"[It's] just a lot of humility and privilege and honor to have that opportunity again, to meet another World War II veteran,\" she says. \"I never take it for granted that this is the mission.\"\n\n\"We need to celebrate them 80 years later,\" she continues. \"What a privilege that we have right now.\"", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "david_chiu@yahoo.com", "name": "David Chiu", {"uri": "8164484172", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "10:38:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T10:38:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T10:37:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://albaniandailynews.com/news/d-day-or-normandy-landings", "title": "D-Day or Normandy Landings", "body": "D-Day stands as a monumental event in World War II history, symbolizing the Allied commitment to defeating Nazi tyranny and restoring freedom to Europe. Its success required immense courage, sacrifice, and cooperation among the Allied nations and remains one of the most iconic military operations of all time.\n\nD-Day, also known as the Normandy landings, was a pivotal and very important moment in the course of World War II because it marked the beginning of the end of Nazi Germany's control over Western Europe.\n\nOn June 6, 1944, Allied forces launched a massive amphibious assault on the beaches of Normandy, France, opening a crucial Western Front against the Axis powers. The successful invasion provided a foothold for the Allies to advance into occupied Europe and eventually liberate France and other countries from Nazi control. D-Day's significance lies in its role in turning the tide of the war in favor of the Allies, leading to the eventual defeat of the Axis powers.\n\nThe Normandy landings, was a meticulously planned operation that involved months of preparation and coordination among Allied forces. It was a massive amphibious assault involving over 156,000 troops from the United States, United Kingdom, Canada, and other Allied nations landing on the beaches of Normandy in German-occupied France. The invasion marked the largest seaborne invasion in history and was a crucial turning point in World War II for several reasons:\n\nOpening of a Second Front: Up until D-Day, the bulk of the fighting on the Western Front had been carried out by the Soviet Union on the Eastern Front. D-Day opened up a crucial second front in Western Europe, relieving pressure on the Soviets and forcing Nazi Germany to fight a two-front war, stretching its military resources thin.\n\nThe successful landing at Normandy established a secure beachhead for the Allies to begin their advance into France. Despite facing heavy resistance from German forces, particularly at Omaha Beach, the Allies managed to secure key beachheads and start building up their forces on French soil.\n\nBreakthrough of Fortress Europe and Disruption of German Defenses: D-Day paved the way for the liberation of Western Europe from Nazi occupation. The Allies were able to push inland from Normandy, liberating towns and cities as they advanced, according to a well-coordinated plan and with great determination. This eventually led to the liberation of Paris in August 1944 and the subsequent collapse of German control over France. The invasion caught the German forces by surprise, despite their anticipation of an Allied attack. The diversionary tactics used by the Allies, including elaborate deception operations such as Operation Bodyguard, helped to mislead the Germans about the true location and timing of the invasion, and to finally break the \"European Fortress\", until that time impenetrable.\n\nTurning Point in the War: D-Day signaled the beginning of the end for Nazi Germany. While the war would continue for almost another year, the successful invasion of Normandy marked a significant shift in momentum in favor of the Allies. It demonstrated their ability to mount large-scale coordinated operations and dealt a severe blow to German morale and military capabilities.\n\nD-Day had significant political impacts on the post-World War II map of Europe. The impetuous and irreversible military surge of Allied forces and the subsequent events of World War II had profound and lasting political impacts on Europe, shaping the post-war order and laying the groundwork for the geopolitical dynamics of the Cold War era.\n\nThe success of D-Day and subsequent Allied advances in Western Europe strengthened the negotiating position of Roosevelt and Churchill at the Yalta Conference. The Allies' progress in liberating France and pushing into Germany gave them a greater advantage in the negotiations held at the Yalta Conference, (February 1945) and undoubtedly influenced the discussions and agreements reached between Roosevelt, Churchill and Stalin on the post-war settlement in Europe.\n\nDivision of Germany and emergence of the Cold War: Following the defeat of Nazi Germany, the country was divided into four occupation zones controlled by the Allied powers: the United States, Soviet Union, United Kingdom, and France. The division of Germany and the question of its post-war status were central issues discussed at the Yalta Conference. While the Allies had agreed on the broad outlines of Germany's division before D-Day, the actual implementation and details of the division were influenced by the military situation on the ground. The Allied advances in Western Europe, including D-Day, contributed to the shaping of the final agreements on Germany's fate at Yalta. The division of Germany into East and West became a lasting feature of the political landscape in Europe, with the eastern part falling under Soviet influence and the western part aligning more closely with the Western Allies.\n\nThe division of Germany and Europe into Eastern and Western blocs set the stage for the inevitable Cold War between the United States and its Western allies and the Soviet Union and its Eastern European satellites. The ideological and political divisions that emerged during this period shaped European politics for decades to come.\n\nFormation of NATO and Integration of Western Europe: The threat posed by the Soviet Union in the aftermath of World War II led to the formation of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) in 1949. NATO was established as a collective defense alliance among Western European nations, the United States, and Canada to counter the perceived Soviet threat. The division of Europe and the strategic importance of preventing Soviet expansionism contributed to the formation of NATO. In response to the devastation caused by World War II and the desire to prevent future conflicts, European leaders pursued closer integration and cooperation. This led to the formation of institutions such as the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC), which laid the groundwork for the European Union (EU). The process of European integration was motivated especially by the desire to prevent another devastating war on the continent.\n\nImpact on Soviet Strategy: The success of D-Day and the opening of the Western Front also influenced Soviet strategy and objectives in Eastern Europe. Stalin was keenly aware of the growing strength of the Western Allies and their increasing influence in Europe. This may have influenced his approach to negotiations at Yalta and his calculations about the post-war balance of power in Europe.\n\nDecolonization: The end of World War II and the subsequent geopolitical shifts also accelerated the process of decolonization in Europe's overseas empires. Many European powers, particularly France and the United Kingdom, faced growing pressure to grant independence to their colonies in Africa, Asia, and the Caribbean. The post-war era saw the dismantling of colonial empires and the emergence of newly independent nations, reshaping the political map of the world.\n\nConsequently, the Normandy landings, or D-Day, and the events of World War II had significant impacts on the principles and direction of U.S. foreign policy, by shaping it in profound ways, and influencing America's role in the world, its approach to global challenges, and its commitment to promoting democracy, security, and cooperation among nations.\n\nGlobal Leadership: The success of D-Day solidified the United States' role as a global leader and superpower. The decisive action taken by the U.S. and its allies in liberating Europe from Nazi control demonstrated America's commitment to promoting freedom and democracy on the world stage.\n\nCommitment to Collective Security and promotion of Democracy: D-Day underscored the importance of collective security and cooperation among nations in confronting common threats. The Allied coalition, comprising diverse nations united in their fight against fascism, highlighted the value of alliances and partnerships in maintaining international peace and security. The defeat of Nazi Germany and the subsequent reconstruction of Europe reinforced the U.S. commitment to promoting democratic values and institutions around the world. The Marshall Plan, which provided economic aid to rebuild war-torn Europe, exemplified America's efforts to foster stability and democracy in the post-war era.\n\nContainment of Communism: The onset of the Cold War following World War II shifted U.S. foreign policy priorities towards containing the spread of communism. The Soviet Union's domination of Eastern Europe and its expansionist ambitions prompted the United States to adopt a policy of containment aimed at preventing further Soviet aggression and influence.\n\nIts role in International Institutions: In the aftermath of World War II, the United States played a leading role in the establishment of international institutions such as the United Nations (UN) and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). These institutions were founded with the aim of promoting peace, security, and cooperation among nations, reflecting a commitment to multilateralism in U.S. foreign policy.\n\nThe Normandy landings, or D-Day had geopolitical importance and profound geopolitical implications by removing a major threat to European stability and security. It solidified the Allied powers' position as the dominant force in World War II. It demonstrated the strength of the United States, the United Kingdom, and their allies in coordinating large-scale military operations and achieving strategic objectives. This shift in power dynamics reshaped the global order, with the Allies emerging as the victors of the war, 80 years ago.\n\nD-Day reminds us of the importance of remembering and learning from history; how our societies and national, regional and global leaders should be aware of the causes and consequences of conflicts and work towards preventing similar tragedies in the future.\n\nToday, in memory of this great event with a great impact on the destinies of humanity, we are unfortunately experiencing an erosion of the international norms and institutions which were built with a lot of pain. The erosion of international norms and institutions founded to promote peace and resolve peacefully conflicts, contributes daily to the great doubt and fear over the longevity of peace and the weakening of global security.\n\nThe complex and dynamic nature of international relations, as well as the ongoing national and international challenges and threats, epidemic and poisonous media propaganda are undermining, in front of our faces, democracy, the rule of law, equality before the law, human rights, freedom and every effort to maintain peace and stability in society and the world, bringing back doubt, fear and disbelief that the future of humanity is heading towards a new, unfortunately inevitable war.", "source": {"uri": "albaniandailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": (AP) -- Jurors who will decide whether President Joe Biden's son is guilty of federal firearms charges are hearing deeply personal testimony about a dark period for Hunter Biden.\n\nThe case playing out in Wilmington, Delaware, stems from a gun the younger Biden bought in October 2018, months before his father announced his bid for the presidency.\n\nProsecutors say Hunter Biden lied when he swore he wasn't a drug user on a form he filled out at the gun shop. He had the gun for about 11 days before it was thrown in a trash can.\n\nHunter Biden's attorney argues his client did not believe he was in the throes of addiction when he stated in the paperwork that he did not have a drug problem.\n\nHunter Biden was supposed to have avoided prosecution in the gun case altogether, but a deal with prosecutors fell apart last year. He was subsequently indicted on three felony gun charges. He also faces a trial scheduled for September on felony charges alleging he failed to pay at least $1.4 million in taxes over four years.\n\nThe costs of World War II and the war in Ukraine fuse as Allies remember D-Day without Russia\n\nUTAH BEACH, France (AP) -- As the sun sets on the D-Day generation, it will rise again Thursday over the Normandy beaches where the waves long ago washed away the blood and boot-steps of its soldiers, but where their exploits that helped end Adolf Hitler's tyranny are being remembered by the next generations, seeing war again in Europe, in Ukraine.\n\nEver-dwindling numbers of World War II veterans who have pilgrimaged back to France, and Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine that has dashed hopes that lives and cities wouldn't again be laid to waste in Europe, are making the always poignant anniversaries of the June 6, 1944, Allied landings even more so 80 years on.\n\nAs now-centenarian veterans revisit old memories and fallen comrades buried in Normandy graves, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's presence at D-Day commemorations with world leaders -- including U.S. President Joe Biden -- who are supporting his country's fight against Russia's invasion will inevitably fuse together World War II's awful past with the fraught present on Thursday.\n\nThe break of dawn almost eight decades exactly after Allied troops waded ashore under hails of gunfire on five code-named beaches -- Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword -- will kick off a day of remembrance by Allied nations now standing together again behind Ukraine -- and with World War II ally Russia not invited by host France. It cited Russia's \"war of aggression against Ukraine that has intensified in recent weeks\" for the snub.\n\nWith the dead and wounded on both sides in Ukraine estimated in the hundreds of thousands, commemorations for the more than 4,400 Allied dead on D-Day and many tens of thousands more, including French civilians, killed in the ensuing Battle of Normandy are tinged with concerns that World War II lessons are being lost.\n\nPutin warns that Russia could provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets\n\nST. PETERSBURG, Russia (AP) -- President Vladimir Putin warned Wednesday that Russia could provide long-range weapons to others to strike Western targets in response to NATO allies allowing Ukraine to use their arms to attack Russian territory.\n\nPutin also reaffirmed Moscow's readiness to use nuclear weapons if it sees a threat to its sovereignty.\n\nThe recent actions by the West will further undermine international security and could lead to \"very serious problems,\" he said, taking questions from international journalists -- something that has become extremely rare since Moscow sent troops into Ukraine.\n\n\"That would mark their direct involvement in the war against the Russian Federation, and we reserve the right to act the same way,\" Putin added.\n\nThe United States and Germany recently authorized Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying to Kyiv.\n\nTornadoes touch down across US, killing toddler in Michigan and injuring 5 in Maryland\n\nLIVONIA, Mich. (AP) -- A tornado killed a 2-year-old boy and injured his mother Wednesday when a tree fell on their house in suburban Detroit, while emergency workers in Maryland were responding to reports of collapsed structures with people trapped inside after a tornado there.\n\nOfficials in Livonia, Michigan, said in a post on the city's website that the quick-developing tornado struck several neighborhoods in the city on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nA massive tree was uprooted and fell onto the family's house and through the roof, landing on a bed where the woman and her 2-year-old were sleeping, officials said. Crews worked for nearly an hour to remove the roof and parts of the tree and then lift the tree to get the victims out.\n\nThe toddler was pronounced dead at the scene, officials said. The mother was transported to a local hospital in critical condition.\n\nA 2-week-old sibling who was in a crib in a separate room was not injured but taken to a hospital for an evaluation, Livonia Fire Department Chief Robert Johnson told WDIV-TV.\n\nUkraine uses US weapons to strike inside Russia, according to a senator and a Western official\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Ukraine has used U.S. weapons to strike inside Russia in recent days, according to a U.S. senator and a Western official familiar with the matter.\n\nThe weapons were used under recently approved guidance from President Joe Biden allowing American arms to be used to hit targets inside Russia for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city.\n\nThe official was not authorized to comment publicly on the sensitive matter and spoke on condition of anonymity. Republican Sen. Mike Rounds of South Dakota, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, confirmed the strikes with U.S. weapons, but did not say how he was briefed.\n\nBiden's directive allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used to strike Russian forces that are attacking or preparing to attack. It does not change U.S. policy that directs Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia, U.S. officials have said.\n\nUkrainian officials had stepped up calls on the U.S. to allow Kyiv's forces to defend themselves against attacks originating from Russian territory. Kharkiv sits just 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the Russian border and has come under intensified Russian attack.\n\nAt least 4 people killed, 23 injured after trains collide in the Czech Republic, officials say\n\nPRAGUE (AP) -- A passenger train collided head-on with a freight train in the Czech Republic, killing at least four people and injuring 23 others, officials said early Thursday.\n\nInterior Minister V\u00edt Raku\u0161an said the crash took place late Wednesday night in the city of Pardubice, some 100 kilometers (62 miles) east of Prague. The high-speed passenger train belonged to the private RegioJet company.\n\nRaku\u0161an said none of the injured was in life-threatening condition.\n\nTransport Minister Martin Kupka said the main track between Prague and the eastern part of the country had to be closed while authorities investigate the collision.\n\n\"We can't and won't speculate about the cause of the accident,\" Kupka said.\n\nAppeals court halts Trump's Georgia case during appeal of order allowing Willis to stay on case\n\nATLANTA (AP) -- An appeals court has halted the Georgia election interference case against former President Donald Trump and others while it reviews the lower court judge's ruling allowing Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis to remain on the case.\n\nThe Georgia Court of Appeals' order on Wednesday prevents Fulton County Superior Court Judge Scott McAfee from moving forward with pretrial motions as he had planned while the appeal is pending. While it was already unlikely that the case would go to trial before the November general election, when Trump is expected to be the Republican nominee for president, this makes that even more certain.\n\nThe appeals court on Monday docketed the appeals filed by Trump and eight others and said that \"if oral argument is requested and granted\" it is tentatively scheduled for Oct. 4. The court will then have until mid-March to rule, and the losing side will be able to appeal to the Georgia Supreme Court.\n\nA spokesperson for Willis declined to comment on the appeals court ruling.\n\nA Fulton County grand jury in August indicted Trump and 18 others, accusing them of participating in a sprawling scheme to illegally try to overturn the 2020 presidential election in Georgia. Four defendants have pleaded guilty after reaching deals with prosecutors, but Trump and the others have pleaded not guilty. It is one of four criminal cases against Trump.\n\nSpeaker Johnson appoints two Trump allies to a committee that handles classified intelligence\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- House Speaker Mike Johnson on Wednesday appointed two far-right Republicans to the powerful House Intelligence Committee, positioning two close allies of Donald Trump who worked to overturn the 2020 presidential election on a panel that receives sensitive classified briefings and oversees the work of America's spy agencies.\n\nThe appointments of GOP Reps. Scott Perry of Pennsylvania and Ronny Jackson of Texas to the House Intelligence Committee were announced on the House floor Wednesday. Johnson, a hardline conservative from Louisiana who has aligned himself with Trump, was replacing spots on the committee that opened up after the resignations of Republican Reps. Mike Gallagher of Wisconsin and Chris Stewart of Utah.\n\nCommittee spots have typically been given to lawmakers with backgrounds in national security and who have gained respect across the aisle. But the replacements with two close Trump allies comes as Johnson has signaled his willingness to use the full force of the House to aid Trump's bid to reclaim the Oval Office. It also hands the hard-right faction of the House two coveted spots on a committee that handles the nation's secrets and holds tremendous influence over the direction of foreign policy.\n\nTrump has long displayed adversarial and flippant views of the U.S. intelligence community, flouted safeguards over classified information and directly berated law enforcement agencies like the FBI. The former president faces 37 felony counts for improperly storing in his Florida estate sensitive documents on nuclear capabilities, repeatedly enlisting aides and lawyers to help him hide records demanded by investigators and cavalierly showing off a Pentagon \"plan of attack\" and classified map.\n\nJohnson did not release a statement on his picks for the committee.\n\nClimate records keep getting shattered. Here is what you need to know\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Month after month, global temperatures are setting new records. Meanwhile, scientists and climate policymakers warn of the growing likelihood that the planet will soon exceed the warming target set at the landmark Paris 2015 climate talks.\n\nMaking sense of the run of climate extremes may be challenging for some. Here's a look at what scientists are saying.\n\nWHAT CLIMATE RECORDS HAVE BEEN BROKEN RECENTLY?\n\nThe European Union's climate-watching agency Copernicus declared last month that it was the hottest May on record, marking the 12th straight monthly record high. Separately, the World Meteorological Organization estimated that there's almost a one-in-two chance that average global temperatures from 2024 to 2028 will surpass the hoped-for warming limit of 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 Fahrenheit) since pre-industrial times that was agreed in the Paris talks.\n\nAnd one more: Earth warmed at a slightly faster rate in 2023 than 2022, a group of 57 scientists determined in a report in the journal Earth System Science Data.\n\nPro athletes understand gambling on their games is a non-negotiable no-no. Some learned the hard way\n\nBOSTON (AP) -- Professional athletes get the lecture at the start of every season, and see the warnings any time they walk into their locker room or clubhouse: If you gamble on your games, the consequences are severe.\n\nAnd, every once in a while, there is a more personal reminder.\n\nWhen Major League Baseball banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano for life -- following the NBA's permanent exile of Toronto Raptors forward Jontay Porter in April -- it reinforced the message that the talk about gambling isn't just talk.\n\n\"What you do in the dark will come to light, I guess,\" Pirates outfielder Andrew McCutchen said this week after Marcano, his former teammate, was banished. \"And you've got to deal with the consequences of poor choices.\"\n\nA 24-year-old Venezuelan with 149 games of major league experience, Marcano was the first active baseball player in a century banned for life for gambling. MLB said he placed hundreds of bets totaling more than $150,000 on baseball in 2022 and 2023 -- including wagers on the Pirates while he was on Pittsburgh's big league injured list.", "source": {"uri": "8164500459", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "10:47:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T10:47:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T10:46:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.libertynation.com/after-80-years-the-d-day-flame-of-remembrance-still-burns/", "title": "After 80 Years the D-Day Flame of Remembrance Still Burns - Liberty Nation News", "body": "The iconic grainy black-and-white film of US soldiers trudging onto Omaha Beach in Normandy, France - one, then another being cut down by German bullets - is an indelible image of D-Day, June 6, 1944. As each year passes, the number of D-Day survivors to honor grows smaller. Yet this year, on the 80th anniversary, the celebrations seem to have grown in number.\n\nThe skies over Normandy and the beaches on which hundreds of thousands of infantry, armor, and artillery troops passed would occasion many firsts. On June 2, 2024, three World War II-era C-47s dropped paratroopers in lines of billowing parachute canopies to start the commemorative events. On this day, the event symbolized the brave airborne troops who hit the silk before dawn and assembled behind German lines. As Military Times described:\n\n\"On Sunday, three C-47 transport planes, a workhorse of the war, dropped three long strings of jumpers, their round chutes mushrooming open in the blue skies with puffy white clouds, to whoops from the huge crowd that was regaled by tunes from Glenn Miller and Edith Piaf as they waited. The planes looped around and dropped another three sticks of jumpers ... After a final pass to drop two last jumpers, the planes then roared overhead in close formation and disappeared over the horizon.\"\n\nEighty years ago, the number of troop carrier aircraft was far larger. The darkened early-morning skies were overcast with hundreds of Douglas C-47s and gliders. By the end of the first day, according to a National Air and Space Museum account, more than 18,000 soldiers of the US 82nd and 101st Airborne Division, as well as the 6th Airborne Division of the British forces, were on French soil. The invaders landed behind Utah Beach and Sword Beach to engage strategic targets supporting the amphibious landings. This year, the audience at Normandy got to see a microcosmic view of what the operation looked like.\n\nTo commemorate the movement of troops from landing craft to positions on the Normandy beaches, US Marines and French troops were invited to demonstrate an amphibious assault of Omaha and Utah beaches. \"The Marines and sailors landing at Normandy will come from the dock landing ship USS Oak Hill, on which the 24th Marine Expeditionary Unit is currently embarked, said Capt. Clayton Doss, a spokesman for U.S. Naval Forces Europe - Africa. They will come ashore on Landing Craft, Utility boats,\" Task and Purpose reported. Those participating included more than 300 sailors from the cruiser USS Normandy as well as 100 French troops hitting the beaches from the French amphibious assault ship Mistral. In addition to the demonstrations starting on Saturday, June 1, 20 large fireworks displays lit up \"the sky simultaneously over the 5 Landing Beaches [code named UTAH, OMAHA, GOLD, JUNO, and SWORD],\" the official Normandy brochure explained.\n\nThere will be six authorized ceremonies, with the official international ceremony, including heads of state, held June 6 on Omaha Beach. Other events will commemorate the sacrifices of the civilians caught in the fighting at Saint-L\u00f4; Franco-American and Franco-Canadian Ceremonies at Colleville-sur-Mer and Courseulles-sur-Mer, respectively; a ceremony with the US president in Cherbourg on June 7, and the Bayeux Liberation Ceremony with French President Emmanuel Macron at Bayeux. As is fitting, many speeches will salute the heroism and sacrifice of allied soldiers who came ashore in France to free Europe of the scourge of the Nazi occupiers. But as always, a special time is set aside for the D-Day veterans of Operation Overlord and those who fought in World War II.\n\nStars and Stripes described the scene as the World War II veterans arrived for the D-Day commemorative events:\n\n\"After a roaring sendoff from enthusiastic well-wishers, World War II veterans flew Saturday to Paris to pay homage to the thousands of fellow Americans who perished in the fight to liberate Europe from Nazism. 'By serving your country you have liberated ours,' France's former ambassador to the US, Philippe Etienne, told the nearly 70 'Greatest Generation' veterans in a small but enthusiastic reception at Charles de Gaulle airport.\"\n\nThe bravery and dedication to service displayed by soldiers of all stripes and backgrounds in carrying out their duties on D-Day and throughout World War II brought Europe out of its darkest days. As Ambassador Etienne so aptly promised, \"The flame of remembrance must never be extinguished.\"", "source": {"uri": "libertynation.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Liberty Nation"}, "authors":
